English: In Sanskrit: Bodhisattvacaryāvatāra
In Tibetan: Entering the Conduct of the Bodhisattvas
I prostrate to all the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas.

To the Sugatas who possess the dharmakaya, along with their spiritual heirs,
And to all who are worthy of veneration, I respectfully bow down.
The way to enter the vows of the Sugatas' heirs
I shall now explain in brief, in accordance with scripture.

There is nothing new to be said here that has not been said before.
I do not possess the skill of eloquent composition.
Therefore, I have no intention of benefiting others.
I have composed this for the meditation of my own mind.

In order to cultivate virtue, my power of faith
Is briefly increased by these [teachings].
And if others of equal fortune to myself
Should see these, may it become meaningful for them as well.

This precious human rebirth is extremely difficult to obtain.
Having attained the state that accomplishes the purpose of beings,
If in this life we do not achieve what is beneficial,
How will we ever again obtain such a perfect opportunity?

Just as in a dark night shrouded by clouds,
A flash of lightning briefly illuminates the sky,
So too, by the power of the Buddha, only rarely
Does wisdom and merit arise in the world for but a moment.

Therefore, virtue is always weak and feeble,
While evil is powerful and utterly unbearable.
Except for the perfect mind of enlightenment,
What other virtue could overcome it?

For countless eons, the mighty sages have deeply contemplated this.
The Lords of Sages saw this very thing as beneficial.
Through this, innumerable multitudes of beings
Will easily attain supreme bliss.

Wishing to destroy the hundreds of sufferings of existence,
Desiring to remove the unhappiness of sentient beings,
And longing to experience hundreds of joys,
Never abandon bodhicitta (the awakening mind).

When the mind of enlightenment is born, in an instant,
Those wretched beings bound in the prison of samsara
Are called children of the Sugatas,
And become worthy of reverence by gods and humans of the world.

Like the supreme form of the alchemical elixir,
Taking this impure body and transforming it into the Victor's form,
Transmuting it into a priceless jewel,
Hold firmly to what is called the mind of enlightenment.

With boundless wisdom, the sole guide of beings,
When thoroughly examined, is found to be precious.
Those who wish to be free from the realms of existence,
Hold firmly to the precious, excellent bodhicitta.

All other virtuous deeds are like water trees:
After bearing fruit, they are exhausted and wither away.
But the tree of bodhicitta (the awakening mind) is everlasting:
It continually bears fruit, never depleting but ever increasing.

Even if one has committed terrible sins,
Like a brave person facing great fear,
By relying on that which can swiftly liberate,
Why would the conscientious not take refuge?

Like the fire at the end of time, it surely burns away
Great sins in a single instant.
Its boundless benefits
Were explained to Sudhana by the loving protector Maitreya.

In brief, the mind of enlightenment
Should be understood as twofold:
The mind that aspires to enlightenment
And the mind that enters into enlightenment.

Just as one understands the difference
Between wishing to go and actually going,
So should the wise one understand
The distinction between these two in sequence.

From the mind of aspiration for enlightenment,
Great results arise while in samsara.
However, unlike the mind of actual engagement,
It does not produce a continuous stream of merit.

From this moment on, for the sake of
Liberating the infinite realm of sentient beings,
With an unwavering mind,
I genuinely undertake this resolve.

From this moment on, whether sleeping
Or even in careless states, the force of merit
Continuously and manifold
Arises vast as space.

This was explained with reasoning
In the questions asked by Subāhu.
For the sake of beings of lesser inclination,
The Tathagata himself taught thus.

Even if one merely thinks:
"May I remove just the headaches
Of all sentient beings,"
Such a mind of wishing to benefit others
Is endowed with immeasurable merit.

Wishing to remove the countless sufferings
Of each and every sentient being,
And desiring to accomplish for each
Immeasurable qualities beyond measure -
What need is there to say more?

Whether father or mother,
Who has such a benevolent mind?
Even among gods and sages,
Does Brahma himself possess this?

For the sake of those very beings,
Such a thought for one's own benefit
Had not even occurred in dreams.
How then could it arise for the sake of others?

Others do not arise even for their own sake,
Yet this one contemplates the welfare of beings.
This special jewel of the mind,
An unprecedented marvel has arisen.

The cause of joy for all beings,
That which transforms the suffering of sentient creatures,
The merit of the precious mind -
How can it ever be measured?

Even by merely thinking of benefiting others,
One surpasses the merit of worshipping Buddhas.
What need is there to mention
Striving for the welfare and happiness of all sentient beings without exception?

Though one wishes to be free from suffering,
One runs headlong into suffering itself.
Though desiring happiness, out of ignorance,
One destroys one's own happiness as if it were an enemy.

For those who are deprived of happiness
And endure much suffering,
May they be satisfied with all joys
And may all their sufferings be cut off.

That which dispels ignorance,
What could be equal in virtue to that?
Where could one find such a friend?
Where could one find such merit?

Those who repay kindness shown to them
Are worthy of praise for a time.
But what need is there to speak of bodhisattvas,
Who do good without being asked?

Even those who provide a small amount of ordinary food,
Those who give just a moment's worth of nourishment,
And those who contemptuously offer enough for half a day -
These are still considered by people to be doing virtuous deeds.

For countless sentient beings over a long time,
The unsurpassed bliss of the Sugatas (Buddhas),
Fulfilling all wishes in their minds -
What need is there to even mention always giving?

Whoever harbors ill will
Towards such a Bodhisattva benefactor,
For as many eons as moments of ill will arose,
Will dwell in hell realms, thus the Sage has taught.

However, if one cultivates a truly pure mind,
The fruits of that will multiply even more.
For the bodhisattvas, even in times of great urgency,
No negativity arises, and virtue naturally increases.

To the one in whom the supreme jewel of the mind has arisen,
I bow down to their body with reverence.
To the one who brings happiness even when harmed,
The source of bliss, I go for refuge.
From "Engaging in the Conduct of Bodhisattvas", this is the first chapter called "Explaining the Benefits of the Mind of Enlightenment".

In order to grasp that precious mind,
I make excellent offerings to:
The Thus Gone Ones and the holy Dharma,
The stainless Triple Gem and the children of the Buddhas,
Those oceans of good qualities.

Whatever flowers and fruits there may be,
And whatever types of medicines exist,
And whatever precious things there are in the world,
And whatever pure and pleasing waters there may be,

Like precious mountains, and likewise,
Forests and secluded, delightful places,
Trees adorned with ornaments of flowers,
And trees with branches bowing under the weight of excellent fruit.

In the realms of gods and other worlds, there are fragrances and
Incense, wish-fulfilling trees, and precious trees.
Spontaneously grown crops of various kinds,
And other ornaments worthy of offering.

Lakes and ponds adorned with lotuses,
Where melodious and charming swans dwell.
The vast expanse of space reaching to the limits of the realm,
All of these are without any grasping.

With my mind, I take up and offer to the supreme Buddha,
Along with his spiritual heirs, this excellent offering.
O noble recipients of offerings, you of great compassion,
Please regard me with love and accept these gifts of mine.

I am devoid of merit, a great pauper.
I have no other wealth of offerings.
Therefore, Protector who contemplates the welfare of others,
For my sake, please accept this through your own power.

To the Victorious Ones and their heirs,
I offer my entire body for all time.
Supreme Bodhisattvas, please accept me completely.
With devotion, I become your humble servant.

Since I am fully embraced by you,
I shall fearlessly benefit beings in existence.
I shall completely transcend previous negative karma,
And henceforth commit no more negative actions.

The bathing chamber is filled with exquisite fragrance,
Its crystal floor gleams and sparkles brightly,
Adorned with lovely pillars of glowing jewels,
And draped with a canopy of lustrous pearls.

To the Tathagatas and their spiritual heirs,
With many precious vases filled with scented water,
Pleasing and well-prepared, along with songs
And various musical instruments, I offer a bath.

Those unmatched robes upon their bodies,
Clean and imbued with finest fragrances, wipe their forms.
Then to them are offered
Excellently dyed garments, supremely fragrant and sacred.

With various fine, soft, and delicate garments,
And hundreds of excellent ornaments of all kinds,
I adorn the noble Samantabhadra, Manjushri,
Avalokiteshvara, and other exalted beings.

With the finest fragrances that spread their scent
Throughout the three thousand worlds,
I anoint the bodies of all the Mighty Sages,
Gleaming and radiant like pure refined gold.

To the supreme object of worship, the mighty sage,
I offer pleasing flowers - mandarava and lotus,
Utpala and all other fragrant blooms,
Along with beautifully arranged, delightful garlands.

The finest incense with captivating fragrance pervades;
Clouds of aromatic smoke are also offered to them.
Various foods and drinks,
Along with divine cakes, are also presented as offerings.

I offer radiant golden lotus flowers,
And precious lamps as well.
On the ground, anointed with fragrant incense,
I scatter beautiful flower petals.

In the immeasurable palace resounding with melodious praise,
Adorned with dangling pearl and jewel ornaments blazing beautifully,
Those boundless decorations of the sky,
I offer to the one of compassionate nature.

Beautiful precious parasol with a golden handle,
Adorned with lovely ornaments around its rim,
Gracefully shaped and pleasing to behold when raised aloft,
I offer this eternally to the mighty sages.

Furthermore, may there be clouds of offerings,
Melodious music and pleasing songs,
That satisfy and relieve the sufferings of beings,
Each abiding in its own place.

May a continuous rain of precious flowers and other offerings
Fall uninterruptedly upon all the sacred Dharma,
The precious jewels, the stupas,
And the holy images.

Just as Manjushri and others
Made offerings to the Victorious Ones,
In the same way, I too offer
To the Thus Gone Ones, the Protectors, along with their Sons.

To the oceans of virtues and qualities,
I offer praise with oceans of melodious verses.
May these clouds of sweet praises
Certainly arise everywhere and always.

To all the Buddhas of the three times,
To the supreme Dharma and the noble Sangha,
With as many bodies as there are atoms in all realms,
I bow down and pay homage.

I prostrate to the foundations of bodhicitta,
And to all the stupas.
Likewise, I prostrate to the preceptors,
The teachers, and those of supreme discipline.

Until I attain the essence of enlightenment,
I take refuge in the Buddhas.
Likewise, I take refuge
In the Dharma and the assembly of Bodhisattvas.

To all the perfectly enlightened Buddhas
And Bodhisattvas dwelling in all directions,
Those endowed with great compassion,
I join my palms together and pray:

From beginningless cyclic existence,
In this life or in other lives,
The negative actions I have unknowingly committed,
Or caused others to commit,

Overwhelmed by ignorance and delusion,
Whatever actions I have rejoiced in,
Having seen these mistakes,
I sincerely confess to the Protector.

To the Three Jewels,
To my parents, teachers, and others,
Through the doors of affliction,
Whatever harm I have done with body, speech, and mind.

Whatever terrible misdeeds I, a sinner,
Have committed, stained by many faults,
All these utterly unbearable actions,
I confess to all the guides (enlightened beings).

Before I have purified my negative karma,
Death may come for me first.
I pray to be swiftly protected
In a way that will surely liberate me from this.

This untrustworthy Lord of Death
Does not wait for what is done or undone.
For the sick and healthy alike,
This fleeting life cannot be trusted.

Though we must leave everything behind when we depart,
I did not understand this truth.
For the sake of friends and foes alike,
I committed various misdeeds and sins.

Enemies will cease to exist,
Friends will also cease to exist.
I too will cease to exist,
Likewise, everything will cease to exist.

Like experiencing a dream,
Whatever objects one engages with,
Become the domain of memory.
All that has passed cannot be seen again.

Even in this single lifetime,
Many friends and foes have passed away.
The unbearable sins committed for their sake
Now stand before me.

Thus, not realizing
That I am impermanent,
Through ignorance, attachment, and anger,
I have committed many kinds of misdeeds.

Whether staying day or night,
This life is constantly diminishing.
With no additions coming from elsewhere,
How can I not be subject to death?

Though I lie on my deathbed,
Surrounded by all my loved ones,
The experience of my life ending
I alone must undergo.

When seized by the messenger of death,
What use are relatives? What use are friends?
At that time, if merit alone can protect,
Even that I have not cultivated.

O Protector, I, being heedless,
Did not foresee such terrors.
For the sake of this impermanent life,
I have committed many sins.

To the place where people's limbs are cut off,
Today they are led, trembling with fear.
With dry mouths and bloodshot eyes,
They appear utterly changed from before.

Seized by terrifying messengers of the Lord of Death,
With frightful appearances and fierce demeanors,
Afflicted by the great and fearsome illness,
How much more utterly wretched could one be?

Who will protect me well
From this great terror?
With eyes wide open in fear,
I search in the four directions for refuge.

Seeing no refuge in the four directions,
Then one becomes utterly despondent.
If there is no refuge in that place,
What shall I do at that time?

Therefore, to the Victorious One, Protector of beings,
Who strives to save all wandering beings,
The mighty one who dispels all fears,
From this very day, I go for refuge.

The Dharma that is realized in their mind
Dispels the fears of samsara.
And to the assembly of bodhisattvas as well,
I likewise go for perfect refuge.

Terrified by fear,
I offer myself completely to Samantabhadra.
To Manjushri,
I humbly present my body.

With compassionate conduct that is unerring,
To that protector Avalokiteshvara,
I cry out in anguish with a wretched voice:
Please protect this sinful one, I implore you!

To the noble Essence of Space,
And to the Essence of Earth,
To all the great compassionate protectors,
I cry out from my heart, seeking refuge.

Whoever, upon seeing him,
Causes the messengers of the Lord of Death
And other hostile forces
To flee in terror in the four directions -
I take refuge in the Vajra-holder.

In the past, I transgressed your teachings.
Now, having seen great fear,
I come to you for refuge.
Please swiftly remove my fears.

Even when frightened by ordinary illness,
One must follow the doctor's words.
What need is there to mention
The constant affliction by hundreds of faults like desire?

Even one of these can destroy
All people dwelling in the world.
If no other medicine to heal them
Can be found in any direction,

To that omniscient physician
Who extracts all painful thorns,
The one who does not follow his words
Is extremely foolish and worthy of reproach.

Even on a small, ordinary precipice,
One must remain vigilant and careful.
What need is there to mention
The long fall into an abyss thousands of leagues deep?

It is not right to sit comfortably,
Thinking "I will not die today."
The time when I cease to exist
Will surely come without fail.

Who has given me fearlessness?
How can I be certain to escape from this?
If it is inevitable that I will cease to exist,
How can my mind remain at ease?

From what was experienced and destroyed in the past,
What remains in excess for me?
Yet I, clinging to that,
Have acted against the guru's instructions.

In this life and likewise,
Having abandoned relatives and friends,
When one must go alone to wherever,
What use are loved ones and enemies?

From non-virtue, suffering arises.
How can one be certain to be free from it?
Day and night, constantly,
I should contemplate this alone.

Due to my ignorance and delusion,
I have committed various misdeeds,
Whether they be naturally wrong
Or prohibited by precept.

Before the eyes of the Protector,
With palms joined, mind fearful of suffering,
Again and again I prostrate myself,
And confess all those [misdeeds].

O guides, I beseech you to grasp my misdeeds and faults.
This is not virtuous,
Therefore, henceforth I shall never do it again.

From "Entering the Conduct of the Bodhisattvas":
The Second Chapter, on Confessing Negativities.

May I rejoice with delight
In the virtue that relieves the suffering
Of all beings in lower realms,
And in the happiness of those who were in pain.

I rejoice in the accumulation of virtues that lead to enlightenment.
I rejoice in those who have definitely been liberated
From the sufferings of samsara for all beings with bodies.

I rejoice in the enlightenment of the protectors,
And in the stages of the bodhisattvas.
I rejoice with delight
In the ocean of virtue of the awakening mind
That brings happiness to all beings,
And in the beneficial deeds done for sentient beings.

To all the Buddhas of every direction,
With palms joined, I pray:
For beings blinded by the darkness of suffering,
Please kindle the lamp of Dharma.

When the Victorious One wishes to pass into nirvana,
With palms joined in supplication, we pray:
Do not leave this world in darkness,
But remain for countless eons, we beseech you.

Thus, having done all these things,
Whatever merit I have accumulated,
By that, may all the suffering
Of all sentient beings be removed.

For as long as beings are sick,
Until their illnesses are healed,
May I serve as their medicine, their doctor,
And their nurse who tends to them.

Raining down food and drink,
I dispel the sufferings of hunger and thirst.
During the intermediate age of famine,
I become food and drink myself.

For sentient beings who are destitute and poor,
May I become an inexhaustible treasure.
May I remain close before them
As various necessities and resources.

My body, my possessions,
And all my virtues of the three times,
For the sake of accomplishing the welfare of all sentient beings,
I shall give away without hesitation.

By relinquishing all, one transcends sorrow.
My mind achieves transcendence of sorrow.
In giving up everything at once,
The supreme gift is to all sentient beings.

To all sentient beings,
I have already given this body freely.
Let them constantly kill, revile,
Or beat it as they please.

Though they may play with my body,
Or mock and ridicule me,
I have already given this body away.
What use is there in defending it?

Whatever actions do not cause harm,
Allow them to be done.
May no one ever
Become purposeless by focusing on me.

Whoever focuses on me
With thoughts of anger or devotion,
May that very focus always be
The cause for fulfilling all their aims.

Whoever speaks ill of me,
Or others who cause harm,
Or likewise those who mock and scorn -
May they all become destined for enlightenment.

I am the protector of those without protection,
The guide for those who have entered the path,
The boat for those wishing to cross over,
And I have become the ship and the bridge itself.

To those seeking a continent, may I be a continent;
To those desiring a dwelling place, may I be a dwelling place;
For myself, wishing to be a servant to all beings,
May I become a servant to all.

Like a wish-fulfilling jewel and a precious vase,
Like accomplished mantras and great medicine,
Like wish-granting trees,
May I become a fulfiller of the desires of all beings.

Like the earth and other great elements,
And like space itself, may I always
Be the basis for the diverse needs
Of countless, immeasurable beings.

Just as space extends to the farthest reaches,
May I be a source of sustenance
For all beings in every realm,
Until they all attain nirvana.

Just as the Sugatas of the past
Generated the mind of enlightenment,
And dwelled in the training
Of the bodhisattvas in stages,
So shall I.

Likewise, for the benefit of all beings,
I shall generate the mind of enlightenment.
And in the same way, I shall also
Train step by step in the precepts.

Thus, those endowed with wisdom,
Having firmly grasped the mind of enlightenment,
In order to fully develop it to completion,
Should encourage the mind in this way.

Today my life has borne fruit;
I have attained a precious human birth.
Today I am born into the family of the Buddhas;
Now I have become a child of the Buddhas.

Now, by all means,
I shall undertake actions befitting my lineage.
So that this noble, faultless lineage
Does not become tainted, thus shall I act.

Like a blind person finding a precious jewel
Among rubbish and refuse heaps,
So too, somehow by chance,
This awakening mind has arisen within me.

This is the supreme nectar
That conquers the lord of death for beings.
This is the inexhaustible treasure
That dispels the poverty of beings.

This is also the supreme medicine
That pacifies the illnesses of beings.
It is the tree of rest
For weary wanderers on the path of existence.

It is the universal bridge that liberates
All beings from the lower realms.
It is the rising of the moon of mind
That dispels the torment of beings' afflictions.

The great sun that dispels
The cataracts of beings' ignorance;
From churning the milk of the holy Dharma,
The essence of butter has emerged.

As the guest of beings traverses the path of existence,
Desiring to experience the enjoyments of happiness,
This abides as the supreme bliss:
Satisfying the great guests that are sentient beings.

Today, in the presence of all the protectors,
I invite beings to the state of the Sugatas,
And in the meantime, I summon them as guests to happiness.
May gods, demigods, and all others rejoice!

From "Engaging in the Conduct of Bodhisattvas":
This is the third chapter, called "Fully Embracing the Mind of Enlightenment."

Thus, the children of the Victorious Ones,
Having firmly grasped the awakening mind,
Should strive diligently at all times,
Without wavering, to never transgress the trainings.

Whatever has been hastily undertaken,
Or whatever has not been well examined,
Even if a commitment has been made,
It is appropriate to reconsider whether to do it or abandon it.

The Buddhas and their spiritual heirs,
Through their great wisdom have examined and realized.
I too have investigated and analyzed.
What reason is there to delay or hesitate about this?

If, having made such a vow,
One does not accomplish it through action,
Having deceived all those sentient beings,
What will become of my own journey?

Even for the smallest ordinary thing,
If one thinks in one's mind to give it away,
Yet does not actually give it,
It is said that person will become a hungry ghost.

Having earnestly invited the supreme bliss as a guest,
If one then deceives all sentient beings,
How could one possibly journey to a higher realm?

Even those who have abandoned the mind of enlightenment,
They too can be liberated.
The workings of karma are inconceivable,
Only the Omniscient One truly knows all.

For a bodhisattva, this is
Among downfalls, the heaviest.
For if this were to occur,
It would diminish the welfare of all sentient beings.

Whoever, even for a single moment,
Obstructs or hinders this merit,
By diminishing the welfare of sentient beings,
Their lower rebirth will be without end.

If destroying even one being's happiness
Causes oneself to decline,
What need is there to mention
Destroying the happiness of limitless sentient beings
That fill the entirety of space?

Thus, when one alternates between
Powerful downfalls and
Powerful bodhicitta (enlightened mind),
It takes a long time to attain the grounds (levels of realization).

Therefore, just as I have vowed,
I shall respectfully accomplish it.
If from this day I do not strive,
I will fall lower and lower.

Though countless Buddhas who benefit all sentient beings
Have come and gone,
Due to my own faults,
I have not become an object of their healing care.

If one continues to act in this way,
Again and again it will be the same:
One will experience the lower realms, sickness, and bondage,
As well as being cut, split, and so forth.

The arising of a Tathagata (Buddha),
Faith and obtaining a human body,
The ability to practice virtue -
When will such rare occurrences be attained?

Like this day free of illness,
Even with food and no harm,
Life is but a deceptive moment,
The body like a temporary borrowed thing.

By such conduct as this,
Even a human body I will not obtain.
If a human body is not obtained,
There will be only evil, no virtue.

When the time comes for virtuous deeds and I am fortunate,
If I have not performed good actions myself,
Confused by all the sufferings of the lower realms,
What will I be able to do then?

If one has not performed virtuous deeds,
But has accumulated many misdeeds,
Even after a hundred billion eons,
One will not even hear the sound of a higher rebirth.

For this very reason, the Blessed One has said:
Like a turtle's neck passing through a hole
In a yoke floating on the vast ocean,
Attaining human birth is extremely rare.

Even by a single moment's evil deed,
One may dwell in the Avici hell for an eon.
So by the negativities accumulated
Since beginningless time in samsara,
How could one possibly go to higher realms?

Having merely experienced that much,
One does not become liberated.
For even while experiencing that,
Other negative actions proliferate greatly.

Having obtained such leisure and opportunity,
If I do not practice virtue,
There is no greater deception than this,
There is no greater foolishness than this.

If, having understood this,
I later become lazy due to delusion,
Then at the time when death approaches,
Great sorrow will arise.

If my body is burned
For a long time in the unbearable hell fires,
Then undoubtedly my mind will be tormented
By the blazing flames of unbearable regret.

This human life of freedom and fortune is extremely difficult to find.
Having somehow obtained such a precious opportunity,
If I, while possessing awareness and understanding,
Am led back again to the hell realms,

Like one bewildered by a spell,
My mind here is simply absent.
By what am I confused? I do not know.
What is there within me?

Enemies like anger and desire
Have no arms or legs,
Yet without courage or wisdom,
How have they enslaved me?

While dwelling in my mind,
Those who harm me with joy and delight,
Not being angry at them and having patience -
This is patience in an improper situation, worthy of criticism.

Even if all the gods and demigods
Were to rise up against me as enemies,
They would still not be able
To lead me into or cast me into
The fires of the Avici hell.

This powerful enemy of afflictive emotions,
When encountered, even Mount Meru
Would be reduced to nothing, not even dust remaining.
In an instant, it casts me aside.

My afflictive emotions, which are like enemies,
Seem to have no beginning or end, lasting for a long time.
All other enemies are not like this -
They cannot endure for such a long duration.

If one practices harmonious rituals and observances,
All will bring benefit and happiness.
But if one indulges in afflictive emotions,
They will repeatedly cause suffering and harm.

Thus, if that which has long been a constant enemy,
The sole cause of the increase of a multitude of harms,
Certainly takes up residence in my heart,
How can I be fearless and joyful in samsara?

The guardians of samsara's prison, in hells and such realms,
Have become executioners and murderers.
If my mind remains caught in the web of attachment,
How can there be any happiness for me?

Thus, as long as I have not directly and definitively
Defeated this enemy, I will not abandon my efforts here.
Those who are proud and angry even at small harms
Will not sleep until they have conquered that enemy.

Those afflicted by suffering due to the nature of death,
Who strongly desire to conquer enemies on the battlefield,
Disregarding the pain of being struck by arrows, spears and weapons,
Do not turn back and flee without achieving their goal.

That which is always the cause of all suffering,
The enemy of one's own nature, I strive to overcome today.
Even if it becomes the cause of a hundred sufferings,
What need is there to mention that I will not become discouraged or disheartened?

Even when an enemy inflicts meaningless wounds,
If one can wear them like ornaments on the body,
Then why should suffering harm me
When I strive diligently for a great purpose?

Fishermen, butchers, farmers and the like,
Who think only of their own livelihood,
Endure the harms of cold and heat and such.
For the happiness of beings, why should I not endure?

When I vowed to liberate
All beings throughout the ten directions to the ends of space
From their afflictions,
I myself was not yet free from afflictions.

Not knowing even my own limits,
How am I not like a madman speaking?
Thus, to conquer the afflictions,
I shall never turn back.

To this I cling and grasp,
Holding grudges and engaging in conflict.
Such afflictive emotions as these
Are conquered only by the destroyer of afflictions.

Even if I am burned and killed,
Even if my head is cut off, so be it;
But in no way whatsoever
Will I bow down to the enemy of afflictions.

Though an ordinary enemy may be expelled from the land,
They can dwell in another place and gather strength,
Then return again when their power has grown.
But the enemy of afflictive emotions is not like that.

Afflictions are dispelled by the eye of wisdom.
Where do they go when removed from one's mind?
Where do they dwell before returning to harm oneself?
Attachment to self simply exhausts one's efforts in vain.

Afflictive emotions do not reside in objects, nor in the sense faculties, nor in the space between.
If they are nowhere else to be found, where do they dwell that harm all beings?
This is like an illusion; therefore, dispel fear from your heart and strive for wisdom.
Why do I needlessly subject myself to the harms of hell and other lower realms?

Having thus contemplated as explained,
One should strive diligently to practice the training.
If a patient does not heed the doctor's words,
How can they be cured by medicines alone?

From "Engaging in the Conduct of Bodhisattvas":
This is the fourth chapter, called "Teaching on Vigilance".

Those who wish to guard their precepts,
Should diligently protect their mind.
If this mind is not guarded,
One will never be able to keep the precepts.

Like an unrestrained elephant of the mind
Inflicts harm without limit,
A wild, intoxicated elephant
Does not cause such harm in this world.

With the rope of constant mindfulness,
If you firmly bind the elephant of the mind,
All fears will disappear,
And all virtues will come to hand.

Tigers, lions, elephants, and bears;
Snakes and all enemies;
The guardians of hell realms;
Witches and likewise demons.

By taming this mind alone,
All those [phenomena] become tamed.
By subduing this mind alone,
All those [phenomena] become subdued.

Thus, all fears
And immeasurable sufferings
Arise from the mind,
As taught by the Perfect One himself.

Who purposely created
The weapons of hell beings?
Who made the burning iron ground?
From where did those masses of fire arise?

All such thoughts as these,
The Buddha declared to be sinful minds.
Thus, in all three worlds,
There is no greater danger than the mind itself.

If giving to the poor
Is the perfection of generosity,
Yet there are still poor beings now,
How did the Protectors perfect generosity before?

All possessions, along with their fruits,
Are given to all beings with a generous mind.
This is proclaimed as the perfection of giving.
Therefore, it is the mind itself that matters.

For fish and other such creatures,
Drive them away without killing them.
By attaining a mind of renunciation,
It is taught that one perfects the paramita of moral discipline.

Unruly beings are as limitless as space;
They cannot all be overcome.
But if I vanquish this one angry mind,
It's as if all enemies are defeated.

To cover all this ground with leather,
Where would one find so much hide?
But with leather just the size of a shoe sole,
It is as if the whole earth is covered.

Likewise, external objects
Cannot be reversed by me.
I should reverse this mind of mine;
What need is there to reverse other things?

What is the fruit of generating one clear mind?
It is like becoming Brahma and such.
The fruits of body and speech are many,
But due to weak conduct, it is not so.

Though one may practice recitations and austerities
For a very long time,
If done with a distracted mind,
The wise say it is meaningless.

If one does not know this secret of the mind,
Which is the supreme essence of the Dharma,
Though one desires to attain happiness and overcome suffering,
They will wander aimlessly without purpose.

Therefore, this mind of mine
Should be well grasped and well guarded.
Apart from the discipline of guarding the mind,
What use are many other disciplines?

When dwelling among countless foes,
Be vigilant, as if tending a wound.
Likewise, when living among wicked people,
Always guard this wound of the mind.

Even if one is frightened by the small suffering of a wound,
And takes precautions against wounds,
Why not guard against the fears of being crushed and destroyed,
Which are like wounds of the mind?

If one abides by such conduct,
Whether dwelling among evil people,
Or even residing among women,
The steadfast practitioner's vows will not decline.

Though I may lose my possessions and honors,
My body and even my livelihood,
And though other virtues may decline,
May my mind never be corrupted.

To those who wish to guard their minds,
I join my palms and earnestly implore:
With utmost diligence, protect at all times
Your mindfulness and introspective awareness.

Those afflicted by illness
Are powerless in all their actions.
Likewise, those whose minds are disturbed by ignorance
Are powerless in all their actions.

For one whose mind lacks mindfulness,
Even hearing, contemplation, and meditation
Are like water in a leaky vessel -
They do not remain in memory.

Though many are learned, faithful,
And diligently apply themselves,
Due to the flaw of lacking mindfulness,
They become tainted with downfalls.

The thieves of mindlessness,
Following in the wake of lost awareness,
Even though one has accumulated merit,
It is stolen away, leading to lower realms.

These bands of afflictive emotion thieves
Are always seeking an opportunity.
Once they find an opening, they steal virtue
And destroy even the life force of a good rebirth.

Therefore, through the door of mindfulness,
Never let it stray away.
Even if it wanders, recall the harms
Of lower rebirths and bring it back near.

From associating with the lama,
And being guided by the preceptor,
The fortunate one, through reverence born of awe,
Easily gives rise to mindfulness.

Buddhas and bodhisattvas,
Possess unobstructed vision everywhere.
Before the eyes of all of them,
I am constantly present.

Having reflected thus, one develops shame, respect, and fear.
Likewise, one is affected [by these qualities].
Therefore, the recollection of the Buddha
Arises again and again in that person.

When mindfulness stands guard
At the gate of the mind,
Then alertness will come,
And even what has gone away will return.

For now, at first, this kind of mind,
Know it to be flawed.
At that time, I shall remain
Steadfast like a tree.

I shall never engage in pointless distraction.
Instead, with a focused mind,
I will always look ahead
With my gaze lowered.

To rest one's gaze,
Occasionally look to the sides.
If someone appears in your field of vision,
Look at them and say "Welcome, it's good you've come."

To check for dangers on the path and elsewhere,
Look repeatedly in the four directions.
After resting, look back the way you came,
Then turn and look behind you.

After carefully examining front and back,
One should go or come.
Thus, in all circumstances,
One should act with understanding of what is needed.

Thus should the body be positioned,
Having completed the preparatory actions.
Then, from time to time,
One should observe how this body
Is actually positioned.

The intoxicated elephant of the mind
Should be firmly tethered
To the great pillar of contemplating the Dharma,
Striving diligently so it does not break free.

So that I may strive in meditation,
Not wasting even a single moment,
I will examine my mind closely,
Asking "Where is my mind wandering now?"

When connected with fear, celebration, and such,
If unable [to maintain discipline], do what is comfortable.
Thus, at times of giving,
It is said to set aside moral discipline.

Whatever one has considered and set out to do,
One should not think of anything else.
With a mind focused on that purpose,
One should accomplish that very thing for the time being.

In this way, all is well done.
Otherwise, neither will come to be.
Without mindfulness, afflictions draw near.
In this way, they will not increase.

When engaging in various idle chatter,
And many wondrous spectacles,
As one becomes involved in all of these,
One should abandon attachment to them.

If you engage in pointless digging of earth, cutting grass,
Or drawing on the ground and such activities,
Recall the precepts of the Tathagata (Buddha),
And out of fear, immediately abandon those actions.

When you wish to move,
Or when you desire to speak,
First examine your own mind,
Then act with stability and awareness.

When your own mind desires attachment
And wishes to be angry,
Do not act, do not speak,
But remain still like a tree.

With laughter and mockery,
Or if filled with pride and arrogance,
With thoughts of finding faults,
Or if with deceitful and misleading intentions,

When I am inclined to praise myself,
Or to criticize and belittle others,
Or when I become angry and filled with regret,
At those times, I should remain still like a tree.

If one desires gain, honor, and fame,
Or wishes to acquire servants and retinue,
Or if one's mind craves respect and veneration,
At such times, one should remain still like a tree.

When the thought arises to:
Abandon concern for others' welfare,
Pursue only one's own interests,
Or speak out with desire,
Then one should remain still like a tree.

When impatience, laziness, and fear arise,
As well as recklessness, idle chatter,
And attachment to one's own side,
At that time, remain still like a tree.

Thus, having examined the afflicted mind,
Striving without purpose,
At that time, the hero should
Firmly grasp it with the antidote.

With utmost certainty and deep faith,
Steadfast, respectful, and reverent,
Possessing modesty and a sense of shame,
Peaceful and striving to bring joy to others.

Not wearied by the conflicting desires
Of childish beings at odds with each other,
When afflictions arise in these beings,
Think "This mind has arisen" with compassion.

In actions free from wrongdoing,
Having mastery over self and beings,
Like an illusion, without ego,
This mind should always be held.

After a long time, having obtained this supreme leisure,
Reflecting again and again,
One should hold the mind steady,
Immovable as Mount Meru.

Though vultures, craving flesh,
May drag you all about,
If your mind does not become displeased,
Why do you now give advice?

Having grasped this body as one's own,
Why, mind, do you protect it?
You and it are separate things,
So what use is it to you?

O deluded mind, why do you not
Grasp the pure form of the tree?
This machine of impure aggregates,
Why guard this rotting thing?

First, this layer of skin,
Separate it with your own mind.
Then the flesh from the web of bones,
Divide it apart with the sword of wisdom.

Even the bones should be separated,
And examined down to the marrow.
Ask yourself, "What essence is there in this?"
Investigate thoroughly by yourself.

Thus, though you search diligently,
If you do not see the essence there,
Why do you still, out of attachment,
Protect this body of yours?

You should not eat impure things,
Nor should you drink blood.
If you should not even examine your intestines,
What use is this body to you?

At night, the fox and vulture
Should guard this for the sake of food.
As for this human body,
It is merely to be used up.

Though you may guard it carefully,
When the merciless Lord of Death
Snatches it away and gives it to birds and dogs,
What then will you be able to do?

Even if servants are unfit for labor,
If you do not provide them clothing and such,
When this body is shaken and goes elsewhere,
Why do you exhaust yourself so?

Having given payment for this,
Now let it serve its own purpose.
Without benefit to this,
Do not give everything away.

Merely as a support for coming and going,
View the body as a boat.
In order to accomplish the welfare of sentient beings,
Transform it into a wish-fulfilling body.

Thus, with your own freedom,
Always maintain a smiling countenance.
Abandon frowns and gloomy expressions completely,
And be an honest friend to all beings.

Do not carelessly throw down chairs and such
Making loud noises.
Do not open doors forcefully.
Always delight in being humble and modest.

Like an otter, a cat, or a thief,
Moving silently and stealthily,
To accomplish one's desired aim -
The sage should always act likewise.

Skilled at encouraging others,
Speaking words that benefit without being asked,
Respectfully receive these teachings with your crown,
And always be a student of everyone.

For all that is well-spoken,
One should say, "This is virtuous speech."
When one sees someone performing meritorious deeds,
Generate joy by praising them well.

Praise the virtues of others in their absence;
When virtues are praised, join in the praise.
If you praise your own virtues,
Know that this is understood as a virtue itself.

All endeavors are for the sake of joy,
Yet such joy is rare even if bought with riches.
Therefore, through the virtues created by others,
One should experience the bliss of rejoicing.

I have no loss here,
And great happiness in the hereafter.
The wrongdoer is unhappy and suffers,
And has great suffering in the hereafter.

When speaking, be relaxed and coherent,
Clear in meaning and pleasing to the mind.
Free from attachment and aversion,
Speak gently and in moderation.

Even when looking at sentient beings with one's eyes,
Relying on these very beings,
Thinking "I will become a Buddha,"
Look upon them with honesty and loving-kindness.

Whether aroused by constant attachment,
Or stirred up by its antidote,
Towards those with good qualities and those who help,
And towards those who suffer, great virtue arises.

Having become wise and confident,
I shall always perform my duties.
In all my actions,
I should not depend on anyone else.

Practice the perfection of generosity and others,
Progressing higher and higher.
Do not abandon the greater for the sake of the lesser.
Primarily, consider the welfare of others.

Thus, having understood this, one should
Always remain diligent in benefiting others.
The Compassionate One, with far-reaching vision,
Permitted even that which was generally prohibited for their sake.

To those who have fallen into wrong ways, the unprotected,
And those abiding in ascetic practices, one should distribute.
Eat only what is sufficient,
And give away everything except the three Dharma robes.

The holy Dharma is the body of practice.
Do not harm others for trivial reasons.
If you act in this way,
The wishes of sentient beings will be quickly fulfilled.

Without pure compassionate intention,
Do not give up this body.
Rather, in this life and beyond,
Dedicate it as a cause for accomplishing great purpose.

Do not teach the Dharma to those who are disrespectful.
Do not teach to those who, though not ill, have their heads wrapped,
Nor to those carrying umbrellas, sticks, or weapons,
Nor to those with their heads covered.

To the humble, be profound and vast.
Without men born, there are no women.
Toward both lowly and supreme dharmas,
Practice always with equal reverence.

One who has become a vessel for the vast Dharma
Should not engage in inferior teachings.
One should not completely abandon one's conduct.
One should not be led astray by sutras and mantras.

When discarding toothpicks and spittle,
One should cover them.
Urine and other waste
Should not be disposed of in water or on open ground.

Do not eat with a full mouth or while making noise.
Do not eat with your mouth wide open.
Do not sit with your legs stretched out.
Do not rub your hands together.

In vehicles, beds, seats, and dwellings,
Do not be alone with another's wife.
All worldly things that cause loss of faith,
Seeing or hearing of them, should be abandoned.

Do not point with your finger;
Instead, with respect,
Everyone should use
Their right hand to show the way.

Do not move your hands excessively,
But move them slightly and make a sound,
Such as snapping fingers or other signals.
Otherwise, they will become unrestrained.

Like the Protector lying in parinirvana,
One should lie down facing the desired direction.
With mindfulness, swiftly arise in mind,
And from the very start, apply yourself with certainty.

From the countless practices of bodhisattvas that have been taught,
One should definitely engage in the practice of mind training
For as long as it takes.

Three times during day and night,
One should recite the Three Heaps Sutra.
By relying on the Victorious Ones and bodhicitta,
The remnants of downfalls are thus pacified.

Whether by one's own power or that of another,
Whatever one may do in any situation,
Whatever training has been taught,
Strive diligently to train in that situation.

There is nothing that the children of the Victorious Ones do not train in.
For the wise ones who abide in this way,
There is nothing that does not become merit.

Whether directly or indirectly,
Engage in nothing other than the welfare of beings.
Solely for the sake of all sentient beings,
Dedicate everything to enlightenment.

Always, a virtuous spiritual friend
Who is skilled in the meaning of the Great Vehicle,
And supreme in the discipline of a bodhisattva,
Should not be abandoned even at the cost of one's life.

From the biography of Glorious Sambhava,
Learn the proper way to rely on a spiritual teacher.
This and other instructions given by the Buddha
Should be understood by reading the sutras.

The trainings appear in the sutras,
Therefore, one should read the sutras.
The Sutra of the Essence of Space
Should be studied first of all.

Because it is always practiced,
And from that, it is extensively taught,
The compendium of all trainings
Should certainly be examined again and again.

Or, for a concise summary,
Look at the collection of all sutras.
The two works composed by
The noble Nagarjuna should also be studied diligently.

Whatever is not prohibited,
That itself should be practiced.
In order to protect the mind of the world,
Having seen the precepts, practice them perfectly.

Repeatedly examine
The state of your body and mind.
This alone, in brief,
Is the characteristic of guarding awareness.

These should be practiced with the body.
What can be accomplished by mere words?
By merely reading medical treatises,
Can a patient be cured?

From "Entering the Conduct of the Bodhisattvas":
This is the fifth chapter, on guarding alertness.

The merit accumulated over a thousand eons
Through generosity, offerings to the Buddhas, and other
Virtuous deeds and good conduct,
Can all be destroyed by a single moment of anger.

There is no sin like hatred,
There is no austerity like patience.
Therefore, diligently
Practice patience in various ways.

If one harbors thoughts of anger and resentment,
The mind will not experience peace.
Joy and happiness will not be attained,
Sleep will not come, and stability will be lost.

Those who have been given wealth and honors,
And who depend on that benefactor,
Even they, when filled with hatred,
Will turn against and seek to kill that lord and master.

By that, friends become weary.
Even if attracted by generosity, they will not rely on you.
In short, for one who dwells in anger,
There is no happiness whatsoever.

The enemy of anger and the like
Will cause suffering.
Whoever diligently overcomes anger
Will be happy in this life and the next.

When unwanted things are done,
And obstacles arise to what is desired,
Finding food for mental discontent,
Anger grows strong and destroys oneself.

Therefore, I shall utterly destroy
The food of that enemy.
For this enemy has no other purpose
Than to harm me.

Whatever befalls me,
I shall not disturb my joyful mind.
Even if I become displeased, my wishes will not be fulfilled.
And my virtuous deeds will decline.

If it can be remedied,
Why be displeased about it?
If it cannot be remedied,
What use is there in being displeased?

To myself or my friends,
Suffering, contempt, and harsh words,
And what is called unpleasant, are not desired.
For enemies, it is the opposite of this.

The causes of happiness arise only occasionally,
While the causes of suffering are numerous.
Without suffering, there is no certain renunciation.
Therefore, mind, resolve to be steadfast.

Overcoming difficulties with faith and devotion,
Enduring sensations of burning, cutting, and more,
Patiently bearing meaningless suffering -
Why did I not do this before for the sake of liberation?

There is nothing
That does not become easier through familiarity.
Therefore, by becoming accustomed to small harms,
Learn to endure great harms.

Why do you not see the pointless suffering
Caused by snakes and mosquitoes,
The sensations of hunger and thirst,
And the afflictions of itching and the like?

Against heat, cold, rain, wind and the like,
Against sickness, bondage, beatings and such,
I shall not be impatient or resentful.
For if I am, the harm will only increase.

Some, upon seeing their own blood,
Become even more courageous and steadfast.
Others, upon seeing another's blood,
Grow faint and lose consciousness.

That is the result of a steady mind
And a disciplined approach.
Therefore, disregard harm
And be unshaken by sufferings.

Even when suffering arises, the wise
Do not disturb the clarity of their minds.
In battling against the afflictions,
Many harms occur during the fight.

Having endured all sufferings,
Conquering enemies like anger and hatred,
These are the victorious heroes.
The rest are merely killing corpses.

Furthermore, the virtues of suffering are:
It dispels arrogance through weariness,
Generates compassion for those in samsara,
Brings caution towards wrongdoing and joy in virtue.

Why be angry at sentient beings,
When not angry at great sources of suffering,
Like bile and other ailments?
All these are provoked by conditions.

For example, just as unwanted
Illnesses arise,
Likewise, even though unwanted,
Afflictions forcefully arise.

Though one does not intend to become angry,
People naturally become irritated.
Though one does not intend to generate it,
Anger arises just the same.

All faults, however many there may be,
And various types of misdeeds,
All of these arise from the power of conditions.
There is no independent self-existence.

Those assembled conditions,
Do not think "I shall produce."
Nor does that which is produced
Think "I have been produced."

That which is desired as the "principal" or "chief",
And that which is conceptualized as the "self",
This very self is thought to arise,
But upon deliberate reflection, there is no arising.

If it does not exist before being born,
Then what is it that desires to be born?
That which is constantly distracted by objects
Will also not cease to exist.

If the self were permanent,
It would be evident as inactive, like space.
Even when encountering various conditions,
What could be done to that which is unchanging?

When acting, if it is as before,
What has been accomplished by that action?
To say "This is the action of that" -
What connection could there possibly be?

Thus, everything is dependent on others.
By their power, one has no power of one's own.
Understanding this, one does not become angry
At any phenomena, seeing them as like a snake.

If one asks, "By what means should something be reversed?
And is reversal not reasonable?"
In response to that, there is nothing unreasonable
In desiring to cut off the continuum of sufferings.

Therefore, whether enemy or friend,
If you see someone acting improperly,
Think: "This arose from such conditions."
Reflecting thus, remain at ease.

If things were accomplished by mere wishes,
Since no one desires suffering,
Then for all embodied beings,
No suffering would ever arise.

Through carelessness, one harms even oneself,
Like stepping on thorns and such.
For the sake of obtaining women and the like,
One becomes aggressive and practices fasting and other austerities.

Some fall silent and leap into the abyss;
They eat poison and unwholesome things.
Through non-virtuous conduct,
They bring harm upon themselves.

When under the power of afflictive emotions,
One even harms and destroys oneself.
At such times, how could those same emotions
Not cause harm to the bodies of others?

When afflicted by negative emotions,
One engages in self-harm and such acts.
If compassion does not arise in response,
What use is there in becoming angry?

If harming others
Is the nature of fools,
To be angry at them is unwise -
Like blaming fire for its nature to burn.

Although these faults are temporary,
And beings are naturally pure,
Still, anger is not appropriate,
Just as smoke rarely lingers in the sky.

If you become angry at a stick or other object that is thrown at you,
That anger is actually obscured by hatred.
Since the fault lies with anger itself,
It is more appropriate to be angry at anger.

In the past, I have caused
This kind of harm to sentient beings.
Therefore, it is fitting that
This harm comes to me now, who harms sentient beings.

Their weapons and my body,
Both are causes of suffering.
They drew weapons, I offered my body,
So at whom should I be angry?

Like a human form made of foam,
Unbearable and full of suffering.
If I grasp at it with craving and delusion,
Who should I be angry at when harm comes?

Children do not desire suffering,
Yet they crave the causes of suffering.
When harmed by their own faults,
What reason is there to blame others?

For example, like the guardians of hell
And the forest of sword-like leaves,
These are produced by one's own karma.
At whom, then, should one be angry?

By the power of my own actions,
Those who harm me arise.
Through this, in the depths of hell,
Have I not destroyed those beings?

Relying on these,
My many sins arise through patience.
Depending on me,
They will go to long-suffering hell for a long time.

While I harm them,
They bestow benefits upon me.
Why then, perversely,
Do you, my unruly mind, become angry?

If I have virtuous intentions,
I will not go to hell.
If I protect myself,
What harm can come to me here?

However, if harm is done in return,
Those beings will not be protected,
And my own conduct will degenerate.
Thus, my austerities will be destroyed.

The mind is not physical,
So no one can destroy it anywhere.
But due to strong attachment to the body,
The body is harmed by sufferings.

Even if contempt, harsh words,
And unpleasant speech
Do not harm the body,
Why, O mind, do you become so enraged?

If others who dislike me
Do not consume me
Either in this life or the next,
Why should I not wish for them?

If I do not desire this,
Which obstructs my attainments,
I shall abandon my gains here,
While sins remain firmly fixed.

It is better for me to die today
Than to live long through wrong livelihood.
Even if I were to live for a long time,
That very life would be the suffering of death.

One who experiences happiness for a hundred years in a dream,
Then awakens;
And another who experiences happiness for just a moment,
Then awakens;

For both of these, upon waking,
That happiness is equally unreal.

For both those who are awake and those who are not,
That happiness does not return again.
Whether life is long or short,
At the time of death, it ends just the same.

Though one may obtain many possessions,
And enjoy happiness for a long time,
Like being robbed by thieves,
One goes naked and empty-handed.

If one lives by gain,
Should one exhaust sins and perform virtuous deeds?
If one becomes angry for the sake of gain,
Won't virtue be exhausted and sin be created?

If that for which I live
Should become corrupted,
What use is a life
That only commits sin?

If you become angry
At those who speak harshly and harm beings,
Why then do you not likewise
Become angry at yourself
When you speak harshly to others?

Since disbelief depends on others,
If you can tolerate those without faith,
Then since afflictive emotions depend on arising,
Why can't you tolerate harsh words?

Even towards those who frivolously destroy
Sacred images, stupas, and holy scriptures,
It is not right for me to feel anger,
For the Buddhas and others cannot be harmed.

Even towards those who harm
Lamas, relatives, friends and others dear to us,
See that they are changed by conditions,
Just as before, and thus dispel anger.

If both sentient and non-sentient beings cause harm,
Why single out and blame only those with minds?
Therefore, practice patience toward all harm.

Some commit wrongs out of ignorance.
Some become angry due to delusion.
Who among them is without fault?
And who is at fault?

Why did I previously commit
Those actions that harm others?
Since everything depends on karma,
Why should I be angry at this?

Having seen thus, by all means,
May everyone become mutually loving-minded.
In this way, I myself
Will strive diligently in virtuous deeds.

For example, a fire that has burned a house,
Having gone to another house,
Spreads to whatever grass and such it finds there.
That [fire] is cast out and discarded.

Likewise, when the mind becomes attached,
The fire of anger flares up.
Fearing that merit will be burned away,
One should immediately abandon that [attachment].

If a condemned man's hand is cut off,
Is it not good if he is then freed?
If through human suffering,
One is freed from hell, is that not good?

If I cannot even endure
This much present suffering,
Then why do I not restrain anger,
The cause of hellish torments?

Though I may experience thousands of hells,
Burning and such for the sake of desires,
I have accomplished neither my own purpose
Nor the purpose of others.

This is not so harmful,
And great purposes will be accomplished.
For removing the harm and suffering of beings,
One should only rejoice in this.

If you obtain the joy and happiness
Of praising others' good qualities,
Then why, O mind, do you not likewise
Rejoice by praising those same qualities?

This joy and bliss of yours
Is a source of happiness free from fault.
It is approved by those endowed with good qualities,
And is also supreme in attracting others.

Furthermore, if you say "This will bring happiness,"
Yet you do not desire this happiness,
Because you abandon giving rewards and such,
Both the seen and unseen will decline.

When praising one's own qualities,
One desires happiness for others as well.
When praising the qualities of others,
One does not even desire happiness for oneself.

Since all sentient beings desire happiness,
Having generated the mind of enlightenment,
If sentient beings find happiness themselves,
Why then would one become angry at that?

If sentient beings desire
To make offerings to the Three Worlds and attain enlightenment,
Why then do they become distressed
Upon seeing only meager veneration and service?

That which is to be healed, you heal;
That which is to be given, you yourself give.
If sustenance is found through relatives,
Will you not become pleased, but instead grow angry again?

If one does not desire [enlightenment] for all beings,
How can one claim to desire enlightenment?
For one who is angry at others' prosperity,
How can there be the mind of enlightenment?

If one obtains it from that,
Or dwells in the patron's house,
If you do not have it at all,
What does it matter whether it's given or not given?

Why discard merit and faith,
Or one's own good qualities?
Tell me, who would not be angry
At losing what has been gained?

Not only are you without sorrow for your own misdeeds,
But you even wish to compete
With others who have done virtuous deeds.
This is the second volume.

Even if an enemy dislikes you,
What joy is there for you in that?
Your mere ill wishes
Will not become a cause of harm to them.

Your desires bring suffering;
Even when fulfilled, what joy do they bring?
If you say they bring satisfaction,
What could be more ruinous than that?

The fisherman of afflictions has cast
This unbearable hook of saliva.
Caught by it, in the cauldron of the hell of mind,
The guardians of hell will boil me.

Through praise and fame's offerings,
Merit does not increase, nor does it greatly change.
One's own strength does not increase, nor does it bring freedom from illness.
It does not transform the body into a state of ease.

If I understand my own purpose,
What self-interest is there in that?
If I desire only mental happiness,
I must rely on ornaments, alcohol, and such things.

For the sake of fame, wealth is lost,
And even one's own life is destroyed.
What use are mere words?
Who finds happiness in such flesh?

When a sand castle collapses,
Children become distraught.
Likewise, when praise and fame decline,
One's own mind is like a child's.

For now, since sound has no mind,
It's impossible for it to have thoughts of praising me.
What's known as "others rejoicing in me"
Is merely a cause for joy, I suppose.

Whether for others or even for myself,
What benefit is there in others' joy for me?
That happiness and bliss belongs to them alone,
I cannot partake or receive a share of it.

If I desire happiness for myself,
Then I must likewise wish it for all others.
How can I be happy
When others are not joyful?

Therefore, when one thinks "I am being praised,"
And joy arises within oneself,
That too is not reasonable,
It is merely childish behavior.

Praise and such cause me to become distracted;
This destroys even weariness (with samsara).
Jealousy towards those endowed with good qualities
Destroys even prosperity.

Therefore, those who remain near
In order to destroy my praise and such,
Are they not engaged in protecting me
From falling into the lower realms?

I seek liberation;
I do not need the bonds of gain and honor.
How could I be angry
At those who free me from my fetters?

Though I wish to enter into suffering,
As if blessed by the Buddha,
The door has become closed and will not open.
How can I be angry at this?

This is called an obstacle to merit,
Yet it is not right to be angry at it.
If there is no austerity equal to patience,
Should I not abide in that?

If I do not practice patience
Towards this person due to my own faults,
Then I am merely creating obstacles for myself
To the causes of merit that are right before me.

That which does not arise without something,
And which exists when that something exists,
If that very thing is its cause,
How can it be called an obstacle?

The beggar who arrives at the proper time
Has not obstructed the act of giving.
One who facilitates renunciation
Should not be called an obstacle to ordination.

In this world, beggars are common,
But those who cause harm are rare.
For if one does not harm others first,
No one will cause harm in return.

Therefore, like a treasure appearing in one's house
Without having to strive or toil for it,
Since enemies become friends in the practice of enlightenment,
I should rejoice in my foes.

By this and my practice,
Therefore, the fruit of patience
Should first be polished here,
For this is the cause of patience.

If one thinks there is no need to cultivate patience,
And says "This enemy should not be honored,"
Then why honor even the sublime Dharma,
Which is a suitable cause for attaining enlightenment?

If this enemy, intending harm,
Is not worthy of veneration,
How can my patience be perfected
If, like a doctor, he strives to help me?

Therefore, since patience arises
In dependence upon intense anger,
That very anger is the cause of patience.
Thus it should be honored like the sacred Dharma.

Therefore, the Sage has declared
The realm of sentient beings and
The realm of the Victorious Ones.
By pleasing these many beings,
One thus reaches the perfection beyond.

From sentient beings and the Victorious Ones,
The Buddha's qualities are equally accomplished.
Just as we show respect to the Victorious Ones,
Why do we not do the same for sentient beings?

The qualities of mind are not one's own;
They are the result of actions, and thus equal.
Even ordinary beings possess such qualities;
Therefore, they are all equal.

Whatever offerings are made to those with loving-kindness,
That is the greatness of sentient beings.
Whatever merit comes from faith in the Buddha,
That too is the greatness of the Buddha.

The Buddha's qualities are fully accomplished,
Therefore, they are considered equal.
With an ocean of limitless virtues,
No one is equal to the Buddhas.

Even if just a few partial qualities
Of the supreme collection of virtues
Appear in someone, to make offerings to them,
Offering the three realms would be too little.

Since all sentient beings possess
A share of the supreme Buddha nature,
By honoring them with our speech to this extent,
It is fitting that sentient beings become objects of worship.

Furthermore, to those who have become unwavering friends
And have performed immeasurable acts of benefit,
How can one repay their kindness
Other than by pleasing sentient beings?

Because one who gives up their body enters the Avīci hell,
And those who benefit them will reap the rewards,
Therefore, even if these beings cause great harm,
One should treat them all with the utmost kindness.

For a while, even one who has become my master,
For whatever reason, does not look at their own body.
How then can I, who am deluded,
Be arrogant and not act as a servant?

Those who bring joy to the sages through happiness,
And those who, when harmed, cause displeasure to arise,
By delighting them, all the sages are pleased,
And by harming them, harm is done to the sages.

Just as a body entirely engulfed in flames
Cannot be made happy by any desires,
Likewise, when harm is done to sentient beings,
There is no way for the greatly compassionate ones to be pleased.

Therefore, by the harm I have done to beings,
Whatever has displeased the Great Compassionate One,
I confess each of those misdeeds today.
I beseech the Sage to forgive whatever has displeased him.

To bring joy to the Tathagatas (Buddhas),
From this day forward, I become a servant to the world.
Let the masses of beings trample upon my head,
Even if I am killed, I will not recoil - may the Protector of the World be pleased.

This protector, full of compassion for all beings,
Has made them his own without any doubt.
These very beings, seen in their true nature,
Why do they not revere that guardian as themselves?

This itself is what pleases the Tathagata (Buddha).
This itself is what truly accomplishes one's own purpose.
This itself is what removes the suffering of the world.
Therefore, I shall always do this very thing.

For example, although some of the king's men
May harm many people,
Those with far-sighted wisdom,
Even though capable, do not retaliate.

Thus, it is not just one thing;
The king's power is his strength.
Likewise, even those who are weak and harmful
Should not be killed or disregarded.

Thus, the guardians of hell
And those endowed with compassion are their army.
In this way, like a fierce king by his subjects,
Sentient beings should be pleased.

Even if a king becomes angry,
The harm caused to sentient beings
Will result in experiencing
The torments of hell realms.

Even if a king is pleased,
By pleasing sentient beings,
Whatever one may attain,
Cannot be compared to the gift of Buddhahood itself.

From pleasing sentient beings,
Let alone attaining future Buddhahood,
Even in this very life, great glory,
Fame and prosperity - why not see them arise?

When in samsara, adorned with patience and such,
Free from illness and renowned,
One lives an extremely long life,
And attains the expansive bliss of a universal monarch.

From "Entering the Conduct of the Bodhisattvas":
This is the sixth chapter, called "Teaching on Patience".

Thus, with patience, diligence is undertaken.
In this way, enlightenment abides in diligence.
Just as without wind there is no movement,
Without diligent effort, merit does not arise.

Diligence is joyous enthusiasm for virtue.
Its opposite aspects shall be explained:
Laziness, attachment to evil,
Discouragement, and self-deprecation.

By savoring the taste of ease in laziness,
And through craving that relies on sleep,
Not wearying of samsara's suffering,
Indolence will arise nearby.

Swept away by the net of afflictions,
Caught in the net of birth,
Having fallen into the jaws of death,
How is it you still do not understand?

Have you not seen
How your own kind are gradually killed?
Yet you remain dependent on sleep,
Like an outcast or a buffalo.

With all paths blocked,
As the Lord of Death watches,
How can you eat with pleasure?
How can you sleep contentedly like this?

Since death will come swiftly,
For as long as possible, accumulate merit.
At that time, even if laziness is abandoned,
What can be done when it is too late?

This is left undone, begun but not completed,
While this is half-finished and still in progress.
If suddenly the Lord of Death should come,
"Alas, I am ruined!" one will think with regret.

With faces swollen from intense grief,
Red eyes shedding tears,
Relatives lose all hope,
As they gaze upon the messenger of death.

When remembering one's own sins brings anguish,
And hearing the sounds of hell causes terror,
The body is stained with impurity out of fear,
What can be done when intoxication takes over?

Like a live fish writhing on dry land,
If you live this life filled with fear,
What need is there to speak of
The unbearable sufferings of hell that await evil deeds?

When touched by hot water,
It is extremely hot for those with tender flesh.
Having committed actions leading to hell,
Why do you remain so comfortably at ease?

Those who desire results without effort,
And the indolent encounter many harms.
Though appearing godlike, they are seized by death.
Alas! They are destroyed by sufferings.

Relying on the boat of human birth,
Cross over the great river of suffering.
This boat is hard to find again later,
So do not sleep in ignorance when the time has come.

Having abandoned the supreme joy of the holy Dharma,
Which is the source of limitless happiness,
Why do you delight in distractions
And agitations that are causes of suffering?

Without laziness and with diligence,
Take control of yourself,
Equalize yourself and others,
And exchange yourself with others.

I should not become discouraged, thinking,
"How can I attain enlightenment?"
For thus the Tathagata,
Who speaks the truth, has spoken this truth:

Even flies, mosquitoes, bees,
And likewise those who have become insects,
If they generate the power of diligence,
Will attain the difficult-to-achieve, unsurpassed enlightenment.

Born as a human with discerning intellect,
Knowing the difference between help and harm,
If I do not abandon the practice of enlightenment,
How could I not attain enlightenment?

However, if I am afraid
That I must give away my limbs and such,
It is only due to confusion that I fear,
Not having examined what is heavy and what is light.

For countless billions of eons,
Though one is cut into pieces many times,
Pierced, burned, and torn apart,
Enlightenment will not be attained.

In my pursuit of enlightenment,
This suffering has a limit.
Like the pain of lancing a wound on the body
To remove a harmful splinter within,
This hardship is endured to eliminate deeper afflictions.

All physicians, through their treatments,
Cure illnesses by causing some discomfort.
Therefore, to overcome many sufferings,
One should endure minor discomforts.

Such ordinary medical treatments
Are not performed by the supreme physician.
Through extremely gentle methods,
He cures immeasurable great illnesses.
