Even in giving vegetables and such,
The Guide first engages in practice.
Having become accustomed to that, afterwards
Gradually one gives even one's own flesh.

When one develops a mindset
Regarding one's own body
As something like a vegetable,
At that time, what difficulty is there
In giving away flesh and other parts?

To abandon wrongdoing, there is no suffering.
For the wise, there is no unhappiness.
In this way, wrong views and
Wrongdoing harm the mind and body.

Through merit, the body finds ease.
Through wisdom, the mind finds peace.
Though dwelling in samsara for the sake of others,
How could the compassionate ones grow weary?

This is the power of the enlightened mind;
It exhausts previous negative karma,
And gathers an ocean of merit.
Therefore, it is taught to be supreme, even beyond the hearers.

Therefore, mounting the steed of bodhicitta,
Which dispels all weariness and exhaustion,
And journeying from joy to joy,
What aware being could ever become discouraged?

To accomplish the welfare of sentient beings, the forces are:
Devotion, steadfastness, joy, and renunciation.
Devotion is generated by contemplating
The fears and sufferings, and the benefits thereof.

Thus, abandoning opposing factors,
Strive to increase diligence
Through devotion, pride, joy, and renunciation,
And through mastery, control, and strength.

My own faults and the faults of others,
Immeasurable, I shall strive to overcome.
For each and every fault,
Even if it takes oceans of eons to exhaust.

Even a fraction of that effort to exhaust negativities
I do not see in myself.
[Realizing I am] an abode of immeasurable suffering,
Why does my heart not break?

The virtues of myself and others,
I shall strive to accomplish many.
Even a single such virtue,
Takes oceans of eons to master.

As for me, in any aspect of virtue,
I have never developed familiarity.
How strange that I have obtained this birth,
Yet made it meaningless through my actions.

I have not worshipped the Blessed One,
Nor given the bliss of great celebration.
I have not worked for the benefit of the teachings,
Nor fulfilled the wishes of the poor.

To those who are afraid, I have not given fearlessness;
To those who suffer, I have not given happiness.
I have only produced the pain and suffering
Of a mother's womb.

In the past and even now,
Due to my lack of devotion to the Dharma,
Such poverty and misfortune have arisen.
Who would abandon devotion to the Dharma?

The Buddha taught that faith is the root
Of all virtuous qualities.
The root of that faith
Is constant meditation on karmic results.

Suffering, mental distress,
Various forms of fear,
And separation from desires -
These arise from engaging in harmful actions.

By doing virtuous deeds conceived in the mind,
Wherever one may go,
There, by the merit of those deeds,
One will be honored with the fruits of virtue.

Though one who commits evil desires happiness,
Wherever they may go,
There, by that very evil,
They are struck down by the weapon of suffering.

Dwelling in the heart of a vast, fragrant, cool lotus,
Nourished by the sweet nectar of the Buddha's speech,
With a supreme body born from a lotus opened by the Buddha's light,
May I, through virtue, become a child of the Sugatas, abiding before the Victorious Ones.

The servants of the Lord of Death completely flay the skin, causing extreme suffering;
Molten copper, melted by intensely hot fire, is poured over the body;
Flaming swords and short spears pierce the flesh, cutting it into hundreds of pieces;
Falling onto an extremely hot iron ground - such are the many results of negative actions.

Therefore, be devoted to virtue,
And meditate with reverence.
Through the ritual of Vajra Victory Banner,
Begin and meditate on pride.

First, examine your resources and abilities.
Then decide whether to undertake the task or not.
Not undertaking it is best,
But once begun, do not turn back.

In other lifetimes, one becomes habituated to it,
And sins and sufferings increase.
In other times and when results ripen,
One becomes degraded and unable to accomplish it.

By the power of karma and afflictions,
One takes pride in these three.
Thinking "I alone shall do this" -
This is the pride of action itself.

This world, powerless under afflictions,
Cannot accomplish its own welfare.
Beings are unable to act as I can,
Therefore, I shall do this task myself.

When others engage in lowly deeds,
How am I any different?
I shall not act with pride,
For being without arrogance is supreme.

When encountering a dead snake,
Even a crow behaves like a garuda.
If one's own self is weak,
Even a small fault can cause harm.

Is there liberation from poverty
For those who abandon effort with discouragement?
By generating proud exertion,
Even the great find it difficult to succeed.

Therefore, with a steadfast mind,
One should conquer all downfalls.
If I am defeated by downfalls,
My wish to conquer the three realms becomes laughable.

I shall conquer all,
But none shall conquer me.
I, a child of the Victorious Lion,
Shall abide in this pride.

Those beings overcome by pride
Are not afflicted by pride.
The proud do not fall under the power of enemies.
Those [proud ones] become subject to the enemy of pride.

Filled with the affliction of pride,
Pride leads one to lower realms.
It destroys human celebrations,
And makes one a servant eating others' food.

The foolish, ugly, and weak
Are despised everywhere.
Those filled with pride and austerity,
If they too are counted among the arrogant,
Tell me, what could be lower than that?

Whoever holds pride to conquer the enemy of pride,
That one is truly proud and completely victorious.
Whoever definitively overcomes even the arising of pride as an enemy,
Fulfills the fruit of enlightenment for beings as they wish.

If you dwell amidst afflictive emotions,
Appear in a thousand forms like beans.
Like a lion among foxes and such,
Be unassailable by the host of afflictions.

Even when great fear and danger arise,
Just as a person protects their eyes,
Likewise, even when fear arises,
Do not fall under the power of afflictive emotions.

Even if I am burned and killed,
Even if my head is cut off, so be it.
But in no way whatsoever
Will I bow down to the enemy of afflictive emotions.

Thus, at all times,
One should not engage in anything other than reason.
Like desiring the fruits of pleasure from play,
What actions should be done by this?

One should be attached to that work;
One should delight in that work, never tiring of it.
Though one works for the sake of happiness,
There is no certainty whether happiness will come or not.

How can one be at ease not doing
That very action which brings happiness?
If one is not satisfied by desires,
Which are like honey on the edge of a razor blade,

How can one ever be satisfied with merit
That ripens into happiness and peace?
Therefore, to complete all karmic actions,
[One should practice] even in the scorching midday sun.

Like an elephant entering a lake upon encountering it,
One should likewise engage in that action.
If strength wanes and difficulties follow,
Abandon it to do it again later.

If well understood, for the future,
And desiring the future, one should abandon this.
Like an old enemy encountered
Face to face on the battlefield,
One should dodge the weapons of afflictions,
And rise up to defeat the foes of afflictions.

If a sword falls in battle,
One quickly picks it up out of fear.
Likewise, if the weapon of mindfulness is lost,
Swiftly recall the terrors of hell and retrieve it.

Just as poison spreads throughout the body
When it enters the bloodstream,
In the same way, when they find an opportunity,
Faults pervade the mind.

Carrying a vessel filled with mustard oil,
While one with a sword sits nearby,
As if threatened with death if it spills,
Thus should the disciplined practitioner be vigilant.

Therefore, just as one would quickly rise
If a snake came into one's lap,
Likewise, when sleep and laziness come,
One should swiftly dispel them.

For each fault that occurs,
I will criticize myself and by all means
Resolve that this shall not happen to me again.
I will contemplate this intention for a long time.

Just as in these temporary states,
Mindfulness becomes habitual, it is said.
By this cause, one should desire
To encounter or engage in logical actions.

Before undertaking any action,
One should have the ability for all things.
Thus, mindful of careful speech,
One should rise up lightly oneself.

Just as the wind controls
The movement of cotton,
So too does enthusiasm control [the mind];
Thus, in this way, accomplishment arises.

From "Entering the Conduct of the Bodhisattvas":
This is the seventh chapter, called "Teaching on Diligence".

Having thus generated diligence,
Place the mind in meditative concentration.
A person whose mind is distracted
Dwells in the jaws of afflictions.

Through seclusion of body and mind,
Distractions do not arise.
Therefore, renounce worldly affairs,
And completely abandon conceptual thoughts.

Due to attachment and craving for gain and the like,
One does not renounce worldly things.
Therefore, completely abandoning these,
The wise should investigate thus.

Knowing that insight endowed with perfect tranquility
Thoroughly destroys the afflictions,
One should first seek tranquility.
This is accomplished through joy in non-attachment to worldly things.

Who, among the impermanent, becomes truly attached to the impermanent?
By doing so, for thousands of lifetimes,
They will never see the one they love.

If not seen, one does not become joyful.
The mind also does not enter into equanimity.
Even when seen, one does not become satisfied.
As before, one becomes tormented by craving.

If one becomes attached to sentient beings,
It completely obscures the ultimate truth.
It also destroys the mind of renunciation,
And finally leads to sorrow and anguish.

By mere thoughts alone,
This life will pass without meaning.
Through impermanent friends and companions,
Even the eternal Dharma will be destroyed.

If you associate equally with fools,
You will surely go to lower realms.
If you are led by those unequal in fortune,
What use is there in relying on fools?

In an instant, one can become a friend,
And in a moment, turn into an enemy.
They grow angry at things that bring joy,
Ordinary beings are difficult to please.

When spoken to beneficially, they become angry.
They also turn away from what benefits them.
If their words are not heeded,
Through anger, they will go to lower realms.

Born alone, one comes into being,

If one cannot take on another's share of suffering,

Those who have entered the pure path,
Just as they grasp their dwelling place,
Likewise, those who have entered the path of existence
Fully grasp their place of birth.

As long as the world is afflicted,
Until four men
Have not lifted it up,
Until then, go to the forest.

Without friends and without enemies,
This body alone dwells in solitude.
Considering oneself as already dead,
When death comes, there will be no sorrow.

Whoever is present nearby,

Cannot be distracted by anyone.

Therefore, in a delightful forest grove,
Where peace and happiness are easily found,
Where all distractions are pacified,
I shall dwell alone by myself.

Abandoning all other thoughts,
With single-pointed focus on oneself,
Strive diligently to
Stabilize and tame the mind.

In this world and the next,
Desires give rise to misery.

Before, by many male and female messengers,

For the sake of sins or for ill repute,

Even when entering into fear,
And exhausting all possessions,

Why do you embrace in your arms
Another, who was born from an impure field,
And whose seed produced that impurity?

From impurity arise impure worms,
Even small ones you do not desire.
Yet the body, which is by nature full of impurities,
You desire even though it is born of impurity.

Not only do you not criticize yourself for being impure,
But like a bag of filth craving more filth,
You desire others out of greed as well.

By putting in the mouth and spitting out
Pleasant things like camphor,
Or rice porridge, or even vegetables,
Even the ground becomes impure and defiled.

If you still have doubts
Even when faced with such impurity,
Go and look at other impure bodies
Cast away in charnel grounds.

When the skin is peeled away,
Great fear arises.
Yet knowing this,
How can one still take delight in it again and again?

The scent applied to the body
Is sandalwood and such, nothing else.
Why then does one become attached
To others due to that scent of others?

If by nature it is foul-smelling,
Is it not better to be unattached to this?
Those who pointlessly burn worldly things,
How can they make them fragrant?

However, the fragrant sandalwood -
What has happened to it here on the body?
Why should one become attached
To others due to the scent of others?

If long hair and nails,
Gray teeth with odor, and the smell of mud
Adorn the body's natural state,
Then nakedness itself is frightening.

Like a weapon that harms oneself,
Why do you polish and clean it?
Through ignorant efforts towards the self,
This madman disturbs the entire world.

Seeing only bones and skulls,
One feels revulsion in the charnel ground.
Yet do you delight in the village charnel ground,
Filled with moving skeletons?

Thus, that which has become impure,
Is not obtained without a price.
By striving to acquire it,
One becomes exhausted and
Falls into harm such as hell realms.

A child cannot increase wealth,
So what good is it when one reaches adulthood?
If one spends life accumulating possessions,
What use are desires when old age comes?

Some wicked, greedy people
Become utterly exhausted from their daily work.
Upon returning home, their worn-out bodies
Lie down like corpses to sleep.

Some travel far, afflicted with suffering,
Enduring the hardships of a long journey.
Though they yearn to see their children and wives,
Even if they circle the world, they will not find them.

Those who wish to help me, yet are deluded,
Even sell themselves for my sake.
Not attaining their goal, rendered purposeless,
They are driven by the winds of others' karma.

Some sell their own bodies,
And are helplessly enslaved by others.
Even wives, when they bear children,
Give birth beneath trees in wilderness retreats.

Fools deceived by desire,
Saying "We wish to live, we must live,"
Enter battle risking their lives,
And become servants for profit's sake.

Some who are filled with desire have their bodies cut,
Some are impaled on the tip of a stake,
Some are stabbed with short spears,
Some are even seen being burned.

Through the torment of accumulating, guarding, and losing,
Know that wealth is an endless source of trouble.
Those who are distracted by attachment to wealth
Have no chance of liberation from the sufferings of existence.

For those filled with desire, there are many faults
And little benefit, like this:
As oxen pulling a cart
Eat only a few mouthfuls of grass.

Even for trifling things that animals can easily obtain,
This precious human life of leisure and opportunity, so difficult to find,
Is squandered by those tormented by their karma.

Desires will certainly perish,
And cause one to fall into hell and such places.
Because they are not great,
At all times they bring about exhausting hardships.

If Buddhahood can be achieved
With just a fraction of that effort,
Then those who desire enlightenment
But avoid the bodhisattva's conduct
Suffer greatly without attaining awakening.

When contemplating the sufferings of hell and such realms,
Desires are like weapons,
Poison, fire, and precipices,
Even enemies cannot compare as metaphors.

Thus, growing weary of desires,
Cultivate joy in solitude.
In the peaceful depths of the forest,
Empty of conflict and afflictions.

In a delightful mansion with wide stone slabs,
Cooled by the fortunate moonlight and sandalwood,
Where silent, peaceful forest breezes stir,
One walks while contemplating how to benefit others.

In empty houses, at the foot of trees, or in caves,
Dwell as long as you wish.
Abandon the suffering of guarding possessions,
And live carefree, without dependence.

Free from attachment and independent,
Unconnected to anything whatsoever,
Content and living in ease -
Even for the powerful, this is difficult to attain.

Having contemplated the virtues of solitude
In these and other ways,
Pacifying discursive thoughts,
One should meditate on the mind of enlightenment.

First, strive diligently to meditate
On the equality of self and others.
Since happiness and suffering are equal,
Protect all beings as you would yourself.

Though there are many divisions like hands and so on,
They are unified as one body to be protected.
Likewise, though beings are different, their joys and sorrows
Are all equal in desiring happiness, just like oneself.

Even if my suffering
Does not harm the bodies of others,
Still, that suffering of mine
Is unbearable due to clinging to self.

When both myself and others
Equally desire happiness,
What difference is there between us?
Why then do I strive for happiness for myself alone?

When both myself and others
Equally do not desire suffering,
What difference is there between us?
Why then do I protect myself and not others?

If suffering does not harm me,
Why should I protect against it?
And if future suffering
Will not cause harm, why guard against it?

The thought "I have experienced that"
Is a mistaken conception.
For in this way, the one who dies is another,
And the one who is born is also another.

When any suffering arises for anyone,
If that very person protects against it,
The foot's suffering is not [protected] by the hand.
So why should one [part] protect the other?

Even if it is not logical here,
If one engages due to grasping at a self,
Whether self or other, it is unreasonable.
One should abandon it to the best of one's ability.

The so-called "continuum" and "collection" are
Illusory, like a garland or an army.
There is no real sufferer that exists;
So who is it that will abandon this?

Without an owner of suffering,
All is undifferentiated.
Because it is suffering, it should be eliminated.
What is to be done with certainty about that?

Why should one not strive
To eliminate all beings' suffering?
If it can be eliminated, eliminate it all.
If not, I too am like other sentient beings.

If you ask why one should deliberately cultivate
Compassion that brings much suffering,
When one contemplates the suffering of beings,
How can compassion not bring great suffering?

If by one suffering,
Many sufferings can be eliminated,
Then one with compassion should
Generate that suffering for oneself and others.

Therefore, although Chandraprabha knew of the king's harm,
He did not remove his own suffering,
For the sake of exhausting the suffering of many.

Thus, when the mind becomes accustomed,
One rejoices in alleviating others' suffering.
Like a swan entering a lotus lake,
One enters even the most torturous realms without hesitation.

When sentient beings are completely liberated,
There is an ocean of joy.
Is that itself not enough?
What more could one desiring liberation do?

Therefore, even when doing good for others,
There is no pride or amazement.
Solely delighting in benefiting others,
There is no expectation of karmic fruits.

Therefore, just as even in small matters,
One protects oneself from unpleasant things,
Likewise, one should cultivate a mind of protection
And compassion towards others in the same way.

Through habituation, even though
There is no inherent existence
In drops of semen and blood of others,
One comes to know them as "self."

Likewise, why not grasp
Another's body as "self"?
My own body could just as easily
Be placed among others, without difficulty.

Knowing oneself to be flawed,
And others to be oceans of good qualities,
One should completely abandon self-grasping,
And meditate on accepting others.

Just as hands and such
Are considered parts of the body,
Likewise, why are beings
Not considered parts of the world?

Just as the notion of "self" arises
In this selfless body through habituation,
Likewise, for other sentient beings too,
Why would the notion of "self" not arise through habituation?

In that case, even when doing good for others,
One does not feel pride or amazement.
Just as after eating one's own food,
One does not expect anything in return.

Therefore, just as even in small matters,
One protects oneself from unpleasant things,
Likewise, one should cultivate a protective mindset
And a compassionate attitude towards all beings.

Therefore, Lord Avalokiteshvara,
With your great compassion for beings,
In order to dispel the fears of samsara,
You blessed even your own name.

Do not turn back from difficulties.
Through the power of familiarity,
Even that whose mere name brings fear,
When absent, will become a source of discontent.

Whoever wishes to quickly protect
Both oneself and others,
Should practice the supreme secret:
Exchanging self and other.

Due to attachment to this body of mine,
Fear arises even from small dangers.
Towards this body that gives birth to fears,
Who would not feel aversion as towards an enemy?

Those who wish to perform rituals to cure
The body's ailments like hunger and thirst,
Kill birds and fish and wild animals,
And lie in wait on roads [to hunt].

Whoever kills even their father and mother
For the sake of profit and honor,
And steals from the Three Jewels,
Will burn in the Avici hell.

What wise person desires this body,
Protects it and makes offerings to it?
Who does not view it as an enemy,
And who does not despise it?

"If I give, what will I use for myself?"
This self-centered thinking is the way of demons.
"If I use it, what will I have to give?"
This concern for others is the dharma of the gods.

If one harms others for one's own sake,
One will suffer torment in hell and such places.
If one harms oneself for the sake of others,
One will attain all excellent qualities.

Those who desire to elevate themselves
Will become lowly, evil, and foolish.
If instead they transfer that [desire] to others,
They will attain higher rebirth and honor.

If for one's own sake, one exploits others,
One will experience being a servant and the like.
If for the sake of others, one uses oneself,
One will experience being a master and the like.

Whatever happiness exists in the world,
All of it comes from desiring others' happiness.
Whatever suffering exists in the world,
All of it comes from desiring one's own happiness.

What need is there for many words?
Look at the difference between these two:
The childish act for their own benefit,
While the sage works for the benefit of others.

If I do not truly exchange
My happiness for others' suffering,
I will not attain Buddhahood
And even in samsara there will be no joy.

Leaving aside the next world,
Those who do not perform the work of servants,
And masters who do not give rewards,
Will not accomplish even the goals of this life.

Abandoning all perfect happiness and well-being,
Both seen and unseen,
Due to causing suffering to others,
The deluded take on unbearable suffering.

Whatever harm exists in the world,
And all the fears and sufferings that occur,
They all arise from clinging to a self.
So what use is this great demon to me?

If one does not fully let go of the self,
One cannot abandon suffering,
Just as if one does not let go of fire,
One cannot avoid being burned.

Thus, to pacify harm to oneself,
And to alleviate the suffering of others,
One should give oneself to others,
And cherish others as oneself.

I have become subject to others' power;
O mind, you must surely understand this.
From now on, you shall think of nothing else
Except the welfare of all sentient beings.

By the eyes and other senses that are dependent on others,
It is not proper to accomplish one's own purposes.
Therefore, by the eyes and other senses,
It is not right to act wrongly towards others.

Therefore, prioritize sentient beings;
Whatever you see on your own body,
Take that and that away,
And use it to benefit others.

Having made oneself lowly and others superior,
Then having made oneself into the other,
With a mind free from conceptual thought,
Meditate on jealousy, rivalry, and pride.

This one is honored, but I am not.
Just as this one, I have not attained.
This one is praised, but I am criticized.
This one is happy, but I am suffering.

I am the one who performs actions,
While this one abides in bliss.
This one is great in the world,
While I am known as lowly and without qualities.

What use is there in being without virtues?
I myself am endowed with all virtues.
There are those who are inferior to me in this,
And there are also those who surpass me.

Moral discipline, view, and other such things,
Are not within my control due to the power of afflictions.
I must heal myself as much as I can,
And even accept harm upon myself.

However, I am not the one to be cured.
Why do you show contempt for me?
What use are his qualities to me?
I myself am the one with qualities.

Those who dwell in the jaws of evil realms,
Who have no compassion for beings,
Yet outwardly boast of their qualities,
Wish to challenge the wise.

Looking at those equal to oneself,
For the sake of elevating oneself above them,
One's own gains and honors
Are certainly pursued even through conflict.

May my virtues be concealed
From all the world,
And may no one hear
Of this one's qualities.

My faults should also be concealed.
I am not one to be honored here.
Today I have found good fortune,
But I am not one to be revered here.

This is for those who have done wrong:
For a long time, I will look upon them with joy.
They will be the laughingstock of all beings,
And the object of mutual criticism.

These afflictions are said to compete
Together with the self.
Are they equal to learning, wisdom,
Physical form, family, or wealth?

Thus, having proclaimed to all,
Upon hearing of my qualities,
Those whose hairs stand on end with joy
Fully experience happiness and bliss.

Even if there is gain in this,
If it is my work to do,
Having given just enough for sustenance,
I should take it by my own strength.

This one should be deprived of happiness,
And constantly afflicted with harm by me.
This one has, in hundreds of ways,
Caused me harm in samsara.

O mind, desiring to accomplish your own aims,
Though countless eons have passed,
With such great exertion,
You have only achieved suffering.

Thus, engage yourself diligently
In working for the benefit of others.
The words of the Sage do not deceive,
So later you will see their virtuous results.

If you had done this deed
In earlier times,
You would not have reached
This state of imperfect bliss,
Unlike the complete bliss of Buddhahood.

Therefore, just as you have developed a sense of self
From others' drops of semen and blood,
In the same way, cultivate that attitude
Toward others as well.

After deeply contemplating others,
Whatever appears within your own body,
Take that very thing and offer it away,
To benefit others through your actions.

I am happy while others are not,
I am high while others are low,
I am beneficial while others are not -
Why do I not feel jealous of myself?

May I be separated from happiness,
And may the sufferings of others be transferred to me.
Whenever this occurs, I will ask myself:
"What am I doing?" and examine my own faults.

Even when others commit faults,
Transform them into your own shortcomings.
Though your own misdeeds be small,
Confess them openly to many people.

By praising others' fame excessively,
One's own reputation is overshadowed.
Like the lowest of servants,
I will be employed in all matters.

This is inherently flawed;
Do not praise temporary virtues.
By all means, ensure that
No one knows its qualities.

In short, for my own sake,
Whatever harm you have done to others,
May that harm, for the sake of sentient beings,
Fall upon myself instead.

Do not forcefully exert yourself
In a manner that is too harsh or rigid.
Instead, like a new bride,
Remain restrained with modesty and caution.

Thus should one act, thus should one abide.
Thus you should not act.
Thus should this be controlled.
If one transgresses this, one should be disciplined.

However, even though instructed thus,
If you, mind, do not act accordingly,
Then, as all faults rely on you,
You alone must be subdued.

Where you have lost me before,
That time in the past was different.
Now I see where you are going.
I will defeat all your pride.

Abandon the thought that you still have
Any purpose for yourself.
I will sell you to others;
Do not be discouraged, offer your strength and effort.

If you become careless and
Do not give to sentient beings,
You will certainly give yourself
To the guardians of hell.

Look at it this way:
I have long suffered from giving.
I recall all the resentments,
While you destroy thoughts of self-interest.

If I desire happiness,
I should not please myself.
If I wish to protect myself,
I should always protect others.

The more one pampers and indulges this body,
The more sensitive and fragile it becomes.
The more one caters to its every whim,
The more it falls into a state of weakness and vulnerability.

Thus, even for one who has fallen in this way,
All the desires of this earthly realm
Cannot be fully satisfied.
Who then could fulfill such desires?

Powerless desires and afflictions arise,
And one's intentions become corrupted.
But for one who is indifferent to all things,
Their prosperity knows no end.

Therefore, do not make room for bodily desires;
For they only increase and multiply.
That which does not cling to what is pleasing,
Is truly an excellent thing.

In the end, reduced to ashes,
Immobile, to be moved by others,
This impure form, unbearable,
Why cling to it as self?

Whether alive or dead, it matters not;
What use is this illusion to me?
How am I different from a donkey or such?
Alas! This does not remove my pride.

By heeding the body's demands,
We needlessly accumulate suffering.
Attachment and anger that follow -
What use are they for this body, which is like a piece of wood?

Whether I have nurtured this body,
Or vultures and others have eaten it,
If there is no attachment and no aversion,
Why should one be attached to it?

Whoever becomes angry when criticized,
And whoever becomes pleased when praised,
If they lack understanding of their true nature,
For whom have I exerted my efforts?

If one desires this body,
And claims to be a friend to the self,
Since all desire their own bodies,
Why then not be pleased with oneself?

Therefore, without attachment,
I shall give up my body for the benefit of beings.
Thus, although it has many faults,
I shall hold onto it like an instrument for action.

Therefore, be content with childlike conduct.
I will follow in the footsteps of the wise.
Recalling words of mindfulness,
I shall dispel sleep and dullness.

Like the great compassionate Bodhisattvas,
One should cultivate the seeds of reasoning.
If one does not strive day and night,
When will my suffering come to an end?

Therefore, in order to remove obscurations,
Withdrawing the mind from wrong paths,
I shall constantly and steadily
Place myself in meditative equipoise on the correct object.

From "Engaging in the Conduct of Bodhisattvas":
This is the eighth chapter, called "Teaching on Meditation."

All these branches [of the path]
The Sage taught for the sake of wisdom.
Therefore, those who wish
To pacify sufferings should cultivate wisdom.

Conventional and ultimate -
These are accepted as the two truths.
The ultimate is not an object of the intellect.
The intellect is said to be conventional.

In this, two worlds are seen:
That of the yogi and that of the ordinary.
In this, the ordinary world
Is harmed by the world of yoga.

Even among yogis, those of higher intellect
Refute those below them.
Both sides, using examples of desire,
Have not examined the true purpose of the fruit.

Worldly people see things as real,
And conceive of them as truly existent.
But yogis see them as illusion-like,
Thus yogis and worldly people argue.

Even the direct perception of form and so forth
Is due to convention, not valid cognition.
Like the conventional view of the impure as pure,
It is false regarding impurity and so on.

For the sake of guiding worldly beings,
The Protector taught things as if they were real.
Those things are not truly momentary,
Even conventionally this would be contradictory.

The yogic conventional truth is faultless;
In relation to the world, it sees reality.
Otherwise, considering women as impure
Will be refuted by worldly experience.

From illusory actions, merit arises,
Just as it does from what truly exists.
If sentient beings are like illusions,
How then are they reborn after death?

As long as conditions gather together,
Even illusions will arise.
How can sentient beings truly exist,
Just by virtue of a long duration?

Killing an illusory person and such acts
Do not incur sin, as there is no mind.
But for one possessing an illusory mind,
Both merit and sin can arise.

Since mantras and such have no power,
The illusory mind does not arise.
That which arises from various conditions
Is itself an illusion of variety.

There is nowhere that a single cause
Can produce all effects.
If ultimate truth is nirvana,
Then samsara is conventional truth.

Even Buddhas are subject to change,
So what use is bodhisattva conduct?
If the stream of conditions is unbroken,
Even illusions will not cease.

When the stream of conditions is cut off,
Even conventionally, they do not arise.
At that time, when delusion no longer exists,
By what means could illusions be perceived?

When illusion itself does not exist for you,
What then is there to be perceived?
If something else truly exists,
That appearance is mind itself.

When the mind itself is an illusion,
Who is it that sees what?
Even the Protector of the World has said:
"The mind cannot see the mind."

Just as a sword's edge cannot cut itself,
So too the mind cannot perceive itself.
Just as a lamp illuminates its own form,
So too the mind clearly knows itself.

The lamp need not be made to shine brightly,
For there is no darkness obscuring it.
Like crystal, which is blue in itself,
It does not depend on anything else.

Likewise, some see others as
Both dependent and independent.
That which is not blue itself,
Has not made itself blue.

When one says "The lamp illuminates,"
It is known and expressed through awareness.
But who knows and then declares
That awareness itself is luminous?

When something is not seen by anyone,
Whether clear or unclear,
It is like the graceful gait of a barren woman's daughter.
Speaking of it then is meaningless.

If self-awareness does not exist,
How can consciousness be remembered?
When experiencing something else, due to connection,
It is remembered like rat poison.

When other conditions are present,
For the sake of seeing, one's own nature becomes clear.
From the application of accomplished eye medicine,
Seeing a vase does not make the eye medicine itself.

What is seen, heard, and known
Is not to be negated here.
What is to be reversed here
Is the conception of truth
As the cause of suffering.

The illusion is not other than mind,
Yet not being other, it is impermanent.
How can it not be other if it's real?
If not other, then it has no true existence.

Just as an illusion is not truly real,
So too the mind that perceives it.
If samsara had a concrete basis,
It would become like empty space instead.

Since the non-existent depends on the existent,
How can it possess agency?
Your mind, without companions,
Becomes solitary in itself.

When the mind is free from grasping,
At that time, all is Thus Gone (Tathagata).
Even so, in mere mind-only,
What benefit is there in conceptualizing?

Even if one knows it to be like an illusion,
How can afflictive emotions be reversed?
For even the illusionist himself
May develop desire for the illusory woman he creates.

That which does this is known as:
Not abandoning afflictive emotions and habitual tendencies.
Therefore, when seeing that,
The habitual tendency of emptiness is weak indeed.

By familiarizing oneself with the imprints of emptiness,
One will abandon the imprints of inherent existence.
By familiarizing oneself with the notion that nothing exists,
Even that notion will later be abandoned.

When something is said not to exist,
And the object to be examined is not perceived,
At that time, how can non-existence, devoid of support,
Remain before the mind?

When neither existence nor non-existence
Remain before the mind,
At that time, with no other appearances,
Without reference point, there is perfect peace.

Like a wish-fulfilling jewel or a wish-granting tree,
Which completely satisfies all desires,
So too, by the power of the aspirations of those to be tamed,
The Victorious One's form appears.

For example, like a garuda bird
That has completed building a ritual pillar and then passed away,
Even though long after its death,
[The pillar] still pacifies poisons and such.

By following the conduct of enlightenment,
Even accomplishing the victory stupa,
The bodhisattva, though passed beyond sorrow,
Still performs all beneficial deeds.

How can there be any fruit
From making offerings to the mindless?
For it is taught that whether present or passed into nirvana,
The result is exactly the same.

Whether in conventional reality or ultimate truth,
It is suitable; the result comes from scripture.
For example, just as with the true Buddha,
So too are the results included.

By seeing the truth, one becomes liberated.
What is the use of seeing emptiness?
For the scriptures declare that
Without this path, there is no enlightenment.

If the Mahayana is not established,
How then is your scripture established?
For this is established for both,
But at first, it was not established for you.

By what cause does one believe in that?
That applies equally to the Mahayana as well.
If the other two are true due to desire,
Then the Vedas and such would also become true.

If it is said that the Mahayana is controversial,
Then the non-Buddhist schools dispute the scriptures,
And even within our own scriptures, self and others
Engage in controversy, so they should be abandoned.

If the foundation of the teachings is monkhood itself,
Even monkhood remains difficult to maintain.
For those whose minds have objects of focus,
Even reaching nirvana remains difficult to achieve.

If liberation comes from abandoning afflictions,
One would become liberated immediately upon doing so.
Yet even for those without afflictions,
The power of karma is still observed.

For a moment, if one asserts with certainty
That there is no craving as the immediate cause,
Although that craving may not be afflicted,
Why should it not exist, just like ignorance does?

Due to the condition of feeling, there is craving.
Those feelings also exist.
The mind with its objects
Will come to abide in some [states].

A mind devoid of emptiness
Will cease, only to be reborn again,
Like the meditative absorption without perception.
Therefore, one should meditate on emptiness.

If you wish to claim that any speech
That enters into the sutras
Was spoken by the Buddha,
Then are not most of the Mahayana scriptures
Considered by you to be equivalent to sutras?

If by excluding one,
All become faulty,
Then why, by the same logic, does not
A single statement by the Buddha validate all?

That which even great ones like Mahakashyapa
Could not fathom the depths of,
You have not realized.
Who can claim it is not to be grasped?

For the sake of suffering beings blinded by ignorance,
Free from the extremes of attachment and fear,
Abiding in samsara yet accomplishing the goal,
This is the fruit of emptiness.

Thus, it is not appropriate
To refute the view of emptiness.
Therefore, without any doubt,
One should meditate on emptiness.

The antidote to the darkness
Of afflictive emotions and cognitive obscurations
Is emptiness.
For those who wish to swiftly attain omniscience,
How could they not meditate on it?

If fear arises from that
Which produces suffering,
Why then be afraid of emptiness
Which pacifies suffering?

If there were a self that truly existed,
One would fear anything and everything.
But since there is no such self that exists,
Who is there to become afraid?

Teeth, hair, and nails are not the self.
The self is not bones or blood.
It is not mucus, nor phlegm,
Nor is it lymph or pus.

I am neither flesh nor blood;
Nor am I lungs or liver.
I am not the other internal organs;
I am not excrement or urine.

Flesh and skin are not the self;
Warmth and breath are also not the self.
Openings are not the self in any way;
The six consciousnesses are also not the self.

If sound cognition were permanent,
One would always perceive sound.
If there is no object of knowledge, what is known?
By what is consciousness expressed?

If absence of knowledge were knowledge,
Even wood would become knowing.
Therefore, it is certain that
Without an object of knowledge nearby,
There can be no knowledge.

If by that same [means] form is known,
Then why is sound not also heard?
If it's because sound is not near,
Then there's no cognition of that [form] either.

How can that which is of the nature to grasp sound
Become that which grasps form?
One is conceptualized as father and son,
But this is not the actual reality.

Thus, courage is neither dust nor darkness,
It is neither son nor father.
It is not seen as the inherent nature
Of that which possesses sound.

Like a dancer appearing in different forms,
When one sees the true nature, it is not permanent.
If that true nature were another form,
It would be a single entity that did not exist before.

If other methods are not true,
Then state its own inherent nature.
If you say it is consciousness itself,
Then all beings would absurdly become one.

The conscious and the unconscious,
Are unified, for they equally exist.
When distinctions are mistaken,
What then is the basis for connection?

That which is without mind is not the self,
For being mindless, it is like a vase and such things.
If, however, it is because it possesses mind,
Then when there is knowing, the unknowing would be destroyed.

If the self is unchanging,
What can thought do to it?
Thus, without consciousness and inactive,
It would become like empty space as the self.

If there is no self,
The connection between actions and their results is not logical.
Since actions cease after being performed,
Whose actions would they become?

The four fruits of actions are distinct,
Yet there is no self that performs them.
Both of these are established for us,
So is this not a pointless debate here?

It is not possible to see
Cause and effect simultaneously.
Based on the continuity of a single stream,
The concepts of doer and experiencer are taught.

The mind of the past and future
Is not the self, for it does not exist.
If the arisen mind were the self,
When it ceases, there would be no self.

For example, when a plantain tree
Is split into parts, nothing is found.
Likewise, when analyzed through investigation,
The self, too, is not real.

If sentient beings do not exist,
To whom should compassion be shown?
For the sake of attaining the result,
It is that which is imagined by delusion.

Sentient beings do not exist as a result.
This is true, yet it arises from delusion.
For the sake of pacifying suffering,
Do not reverse the delusion of the result.

The pride that is the cause of suffering
Grows due to delusion about the self.
If you ask how to reverse this,
Meditating on selflessness is supreme.

The body is not the feet or calves,
Nor is it the thighs or waist.
The belly and back are not the body,
Nor are the chest and shoulders the body.

The ribs and sides are not the body,
Nor are the armpits and shoulders the body.
The internal organs are also not it,
And if the head and neck are not the body,
Then what indeed is this body?

If this entire body
Were to abide in just one part,
The parts would abide in parts,
But where would the self itself abide?

If the self resided in all parts of the body,
Such as the hands and so forth,
Then however many parts there are,
Like hands and such,
That many bodies there would be.

If there is no body outside or inside,
How can there be a body in hands and such?
If there is nothing other than hands and such,
How then can that [body] exist?

Therefore, due to ignorance,
One perceives a body in that which has no body.
By the distinction of arranged shapes,
Just as one perceives a person in a scarecrow.

As long as the collection of conditions persists,
The body appears like a person.
Likewise, as long as there are hands and such,
For that duration, that body appears.

Just as the hand is a collection of fingers,
So too it becomes something in itself.
Likewise, as it is a collection of joints,
The joints also divide into their own parts.

Even when divided into particles,
Those particles too, by division of their parts,
And those divisions, being free of parts,
Are like space - thus even particles do not exist.

Thus, who with discernment would cling
To forms that are like a dream?
When the body is thus non-existent,
Where is man, where is woman?

If suffering truly exists,
Why does it not harm great joy?
If sorrow and anguish are real,
Why do we not delight in pleasant things?

If one does not experience that
Which is suppressed by the powerful,
How can there be feeling
For that which is not personally experienced?

Even subtle suffering exists.
Is this not the removal of the gross?
If one says it is merely pleasure other than that,
Even that subtlety is of that [suffering] nature.

If suffering does not arise
When adverse conditions occur,
Is it not established that
Clinging to the concept of feeling
Is itself the apparent attachment?

Therefore, for this very reason,
Cultivate this discerning wisdom as the antidote.
Arising from the field of analysis,
It is the food of meditators and yogis.

If the senses and their objects have parts,
Where would they meet?
If they have no parts, they are one,
So how could one thing meet another?

Atoms do not enter into other atoms.
That is the state of equality without gaps.
What has not entered cannot mix,
And what has not mixed cannot meet.

How can there be contact
With that which has no parts?
If you see how partless things
Can make contact, please explain.

For consciousness without a body,
Contact is not possible.
Since aggregates have no inherent existence,
As previously analyzed in detail.

If there is no contact in this way,
From where does feeling arise?
For what purpose is this effort?
What causes harm to what?

When there is no perceiver,
And perception does not exist,
Upon seeing this state,
Why would craving not cease?

Seeing or touching,
Like a dream or illusion in nature,
Because they arise together with mind,
That sensation does not truly see.

Though born in earlier and later times,
One may remember, but does not experience.
One does not experience oneself,
Nor do others experience it.

There is no experiencer [of sensations],
Therefore, sensation itself is not real.
Thus, for this selfless collection [of aggregates],
How could this [sensation] cause any harm?

The mind does not abide in the senses,
Nor in forms and so forth, nor in between.
It is not found within, nor without,
Nor is it found elsewhere.

That which is not the body, not elsewhere,
Not mixed, nor separate anywhere,
That is nothing whatsoever; therefore,
The nature of beings is nirvana.

If knowledge exists prior to the object of knowledge,
Upon what does it focus to arise?
If knowledge and the object of knowledge exist simultaneously,
Upon what does it focus to arise?

However, if the object of knowledge exists afterwards,
Then from what does cognition arise?
Thus, for all phenomena,
Their arising cannot be comprehended.

If there were no conventional truth,
How could there be two truths?
And if that were due to another conventional [truth],
How could sentient beings ever pass beyond sorrow?

This is the conceptual thought of others;
That is not one's own conventional reality.
If later that is ascertained, then it exists;
If not, conventional reality itself does not exist.

Thought and the object of thought,
These two are mutually dependent.
Just as they are conventionally known,
All analysis is expressed based on this.

When one analyzes with discerning wisdom,
And investigates with that very discernment,
Then even that discernment itself
Is endless, due to [the nature of] discernment.

When thoroughly analyzing the object of analysis,
There is no basis for discriminating awareness.
Because there is no basis, it does not arise.
That too is said to be beyond sorrow (nirvana).

According to whom are these two true?
That itself remains extremely difficult.
If results are achieved through the power of cognition,
What basis is there for the existence of cognition itself?

However, if knowledge arises from the knowable,
On what does the knowable itself depend?
If they exist in mutual dependence,
Then both will cease to exist.

If there is no son, there is no father,
So from where did the son arise?
Without a son, there is no father,
Likewise, neither of these two exist.

The sprout is born from the seed,
And is understood by that very seed.
Knowledge arises from the knowable,
So how can one not understand its existence?

If by a consciousness other than the sprout,
One realizes that the seed exists,
Then by what means does one realize
The very existence of the consciousness that realizes that object?

For now, through direct perception of the world,
All causes are seen.
The distinctions of lotus stems and such
Are produced by the distinctions of causes.

If asked, "What causes the differentiation of causes?"
It is from the very differentiation of previous causes.
Why are causes able to produce effects?
It is from the very power of previous causes.

If Ishvara (the Lord) is the cause of beings,
For now, please state what Ishvara is.
If you say the elements, that may be so.
Why exhaust yourself even over mere names?

However, [it is] many things like earth and so on,
Impermanent, unmoving, not divine,
To be trodden upon, and impure.
Therefore, it is not the nature of the Lord.

Since the supreme lord is not space and is immovable,
Since the self has already been refuted before,
What is the use of speaking of an inconceivable agent
Or of that which is inconceivable?

What is it that desires to produce that?
Am I not eternal, like that and the earth and such,
And also the essence of the powerful lord?
Knowledge arises from the objects of knowledge.

From beginningless time, happiness and suffering arise from karma.
What can be said to be produced by that?
If there is no beginning to the cause,
How can there be a beginning to the result?

Why does it always act without reason?
It does not depend on anything else.
If it is not done by that and nothing else exists,
What could this possibly depend on?

If one considers, it is the assembly itself
That is the cause, not a supreme being.
When assembled, it has no power to not arise,
And without that, it has no power to arise.

If the divine acts without desire,
It would be subject to others' control.
If it acts with desire, it depends on that desire.
Either way, how can it be truly divine?

Those who claim atoms are permanent,
Have already been refuted earlier.
The Samkhyas assert that the permanent Pradhana
Is the cause of all beings.

Courage, energy, and darkness -
These qualities dwelling in equilibrium
Are called the "principal" or "primary" state.
When unbalanced, they are said to be in motion.

It is not logical for one thing to have three inherent natures.
Therefore, that [one thing with three natures] does not exist.
Likewise, qualities do not exist,
For they too are separately threefold.

Without merit, even sound and such
Become extremely distant from existence.
For mindless things like clothes and so on,
It is not possible for happiness and the like to exist.

Things exist in the nature of their causes.
Have you not examined the nature of things?
Your causes are happiness and such.
From that, cloth and such do not arise.

From things like cloth come pleasure and so forth.
Without those, there is no pleasure and so forth.
Pleasure and so forth as permanent
Are never observed at any time.

If happiness and such are clearly existent,
Why is experience not grasped?
If that itself becomes subtle,
How can it be both coarse and subtle?

Having abandoned the gross, becoming subtle,
Those subtle and gross are impermanent.
Likewise, all phenomena
Why not accept as impermanent?

If bliss is nothing other than the coarse,
Bliss would be clear and impermanent.
If you assert that nothing whatsoever
Can arise from non-existence, as it does not exist,

Though you do not wish for unclear arising,
It remains nonetheless.
If the effect dwells within the cause,
Then eating food would become eating filth.

With the price of cloth, buy cotton seeds,
And distribute them among people.
If the ignorant in this world do not see,
The wise will understand and preserve this truth.

That knowledge exists even in the world,
So why is it not seen?
If the world is not a valid cognizer,
Then even seeing clearly is not true.

If the valid cognition is not valid,
Would not what it measures become false?
In that case, emptiness itself
Would therefore become untenable to meditate upon.

Without touching the conceptualized entity,
One does not grasp its non-existence.
Therefore, whatever is a false entity,
Its non-existence is clearly false as well.

Therefore, in a dream where a child dies,
The thought that "the child is gone"
Is an obstacle to the notion
That the child exists. Yet this too is false.

Therefore, upon such analysis,
Nothing exists without a cause.
Neither individually nor in combination
Do conditions abide.

It does not come from elsewhere,
Nor does it stay, nor does it go.
That which the deluded take as real -
How is it different from an illusion?

That which is created by illusion,
And that which is produced by causes,
From where does it come,
And where does it go? Investigate this.

That which appears when something is near,
But does not exist when that thing is absent,
Is like a reflection - an artificial image.
How can such a thing possess true existence?

For that which already exists,
What need is there for a cause?
And if it does not exist,
What need is there for a cause?

Even with a hundred billion causes,
That which does not exist cannot be transformed.
How can that state be real?
And what else could become real?

If non-existence is impossible,
How can existence ever come to be?
Without things coming into being,
Non-existence cannot be separated from them.

If not separated from non-existence,
The possibility of existence cannot occur.
Yet existence cannot become non-existent,
For that would lead to the fallacy of two intrinsic natures.

Thus, there is no cessation,
Nor is there any real existence.
Therefore, all these beings
Are eternally unborn and unceased.

Sentient beings are like a dream;
When thoroughly examined, they are like a plantain tree.
Between nirvana and samsara,
There is no real difference in their nature.

In regard to empty phenomena,
What is there to gain or lose?
Who is there to honor
Or to thoroughly despise?

From what does happiness and suffering arise?
What is there to dislike, what is there to like?
If one searches for their true nature,
What is it that craves, and what is craved for?

Upon examination, this world of the living:
Who here will die?
What is to come, what has already occurred?
Who are our relatives and friends?

All things are like space;
May I fully grasp this truth.
Those who desire happiness for themselves
Are the causes of conflict and excitement.

They become greatly agitated and rejoice,
Engage in sorrow, striving, and disputes,
Mutually cutting and piercing each other,
And sustain themselves with great difficulty through evil deeds.

Again and again one is reborn in happy realms,
Experiencing many pleasures.
But after death, one falls into
The long-lasting, unbearable sufferings of the lower realms.

In the realm of existence, there are many precipices.
There, it is not exactly like this.
There too, due to mutual contradictions,
In existence, there is nothing quite like this reality.

Moreover, the incomparable, unbearable
Ocean of suffering is boundless.
There, one has such little strength,
And there, life itself is so short.

Even there, the efforts of:
Living and being healthy,
Doing and toiling when hungry,
Sleeping and harming, and likewise,
Associating with the childish, are meaningless.

Life passes swiftly without meaning;
True wisdom is extremely difficult to attain.
Even then, the habit of distraction
Is hard to reverse - what method could there be?

Into that great lower realm,
Demons strive to make one fall.
There, many wrong paths abound,
And doubt is difficult to overcome.

Once again, it is difficult to find leisure,
Extremely difficult to encounter a Buddha's arising.
The river of afflictions is hard to abandon,
Alas, suffering continues on and on.

Though they suffer greatly,
They do not see their own suffering.
These beings who dwell in the river of suffering -
Alas! They are worthy of lamentation.

For example, some repeatedly bathe,
Then repeatedly enter into fire.
Thus, though dwelling in extreme suffering,
They still imagine themselves to be happy.

Thus, living as if there were no aging and death,
Indulging in worldly activities,
Having killed [virtues] from the very beginning,
One will fall into the unbearable lower realms.

Thus, for those tormented by the fires of suffering,
When will I become one who brings peace
Through a rain shower of my own happiness,
Well-born from clouds of merit?

At some point, in a non-conceptual way,
Respectfully accumulate merit,
For those ruined by conceptualization,
Emptiness will be revealed.

From "Entering the Conduct of the Bodhisattvas":
Chapter Nine - The Perfection of Wisdom

By the virtue of my composing
This introduction to the conduct of enlightenment,
May all beings enter into
The practice of enlightened conduct.

In all directions, may those beings
Whose bodies and minds suffer illness,
Through my merit,
Obtain an ocean of happiness and joy.

For as long as they remain in samsara,
May they never fall from happiness.
May all beings attain the unceasing joy
Of the bodhisattvas.

May all sentient beings in the hells
That exist throughout the world systems
Experience the joy and happiness
Of those in the blissful realms.

tags:


May those suffering from cold find warmth.
From the great cloud of bodhisattvas,
May the endless rivers that flow forth
Cool those afflicted by heat.

May the forest of sword-like leaves
Become a dense sandalwood grove.
May even the trunks of the thorn trees
Grow into wish-fulfilling trees.

tags:


May the regions of hell become delightful places,
Adorned by the melodious calls of blue ducks, geese,
And other birds with sweet voices.
May lotus-filled lakes with fragrant scents
Transform the hellish grounds into places of joy.

May the heaps of ashes turn into mounds of precious jewels.
May the scorched earth become a crystal ground.
May the crushed mountains transform into offering palaces,
Filled with Buddhas, immeasurable celestial mansions.

tags:


May the rain of burning coals and weapons
From this day forward become a rain of flowers.
May those who strike each other with weapons
From now on throw flowers in playful sport instead.

Those sunk in a pit of fire without a river,
Their flesh decayed, bones white as jasmine flowers.
By the power of my virtue, may they attain divine bodies,
And dwell with goddesses in gently flowing streams.

Why are the messengers of death, hawks, and fearsome vultures terrified here?
Wondering whose great power this is that dispels all darkness and brings joy and bliss,
Looking upward, they see Vajrapani blazing in the midst of the sky.
May we, freed from sin by the force of great joy, go forth together with him.

By a shower of flowers mixed with scented water falling down,
The embers of hell are seen to be extinguished with a hissing sound.
Suddenly filled with joy, they wonder "What is this?"
May the hell beings then behold the Lotus-in-Hand (Avalokiteshvara).

Friends, cast aside your fears and come quickly here to us!
By whose power all suffering is dispelled and joy rushes forth,
Who completely protects all beings, in whom bodhicitta and compassion have arisen,
What has become of that fearless youth with blazing topknot who removes all terrors?

The crowns of a hundred deities bow to worship your lotus feet,
While tears of compassion rain down like showers of many flowers upon your head.
Behold this scene of a thousand goddesses in lovely celestial mansions singing hymns of praise.
Having seen such a vision of Manjushri, may the clamor of hell-beings now be silenced.

Thus, by my virtuous roots, may all beings see
Bodhisattvas like Samantabhadra, free from obscurations,
Bringing down a cool, fragrant, and pleasant rain of bliss,
And may those beings in hell realms become truly joyful.

May all animals be free from the fear
Of being eaten by one another.
Like the humans of Uttarakuru,
May all hungry ghosts find happiness.

May the stream of milk flowing from the hand
Of the noble Avalokiteshvara
Satisfy the hungry ghosts,
And may they be bathed and always cooled.

tags:


May the blind regain their sight,
May the deaf always hear sounds.
Like the goddess of illusion,
May pregnant women give birth without harm.

May the naked obtain clothes,
May the hungry obtain food,
May the thirsty obtain water,
And may they receive delicious drinks.

May the poor obtain wealth.
May those who are sorrowful and suffering find joy.
May the despondent be encouraged,
And may they attain perfect stability.

tags:


May all sentient beings who are ill
Be swiftly freed from their sickness.
May all the diseases of beings
Without exception never arise again.

May the frightened become fearless.
May those who are bound be liberated.
May the powerless become powerful.
May all beings' minds be gentle towards one another.

May all travelers in all directions
Find happiness wherever they go.
May the purpose for which they journey
Be effortlessly accomplished without striving.

May those who board boats and ships
Have their wishes fulfilled in their minds.
After safely reaching the shore,
May they rejoice together with their loved ones.

May those who have strayed onto sorrowful paths,
Upon meeting true guides,
Without fear of thieves, tigers, and other dangers,
Travel easily and tirelessly to their destination.

In desolate places without paths, where danger lurks,
For children, the elderly, and those without protection,
For those who are asleep, intoxicated, or deeply inebriated,
May the deities provide protection and safeguarding.

May I be free from all weariness and fatigue,
Endowed with faith, wisdom, and compassion,
With excellent food and conduct,
And always remember my past lives.

May all things be like the treasury of space,
With enjoyments that never run out.
Without dispute and without harm,
May we freely partake of them.

May those sentient beings of little majesty
Become beings of great majesty.
May those ascetics with ugly forms
Attain perfect, excellent forms.

May all the women in the world
Be reborn as men.
May the lowly attain high status,
And may pride be conquered.

By this merit of mine,
May all sentient beings without exception
Abandon all negativities,
And always engage in virtuous deeds.

May I never be separated from the mind of enlightenment,
May I be devoted to the practices of enlightenment,
May I be fully embraced by all the Buddhas,
And may I abandon all the works of Mara (negative forces).

May all those sentient beings
Have immeasurably long lives.
May they always live in happiness,
And may the sound of death never be heard.

May all directions be filled
With gardens of wish-fulfilling trees,
Resounding with the sweet Dharma
Proclaimed by Buddhas and their heirs.

Everywhere the ground is pure,
Free from pebbles and the like.
Smooth as the palm of a hand,
It becomes naturally soft like lapis lazuli.

In the entire mandala of the assembly,
Many bodhisattvas
Adorn the earth
With their own virtues and remain seated.

May all beings hear the sound of Dharma
Unceasingly from birds and trees,
From all rays of light,
And even from the sky itself.

May they always encounter Buddhas
And the sons of Buddhas.
With infinite clouds of offerings,
May they make offerings to the gurus of beings.

May the deities bring timely rain,
May the crops be bountiful and abundant.
May the rulers govern in accordance with dharma,
And may the world prosper and flourish.

May medicines be endowed with potency,
May the recitation of secret mantras be accomplished,
May dakinis, rakshasas, and others
Be filled with minds of compassion.

May no being suffer,
May none be afraid or despised,
May none experience mental distress.

May the monasteries be adorned with study and recitation,
And may they remain in excellent condition.
May the monastic community always be in harmony,
And may the purposes of the Sangha be accomplished.

May the monks who desire training
Also attain solitude.
Having abandoned all distractions,
May they meditate with a pliant mind.

May the nuns be endowed with attainments,
And abandon quarrels and harmful acts.
Likewise, may all those who have gone forth
Be without any decline in their moral discipline.

Having become disillusioned with immoral conduct,
May I always strive to exhaust negative karma.
Having attained a fortunate rebirth,
May I not falter in my spiritual discipline even there.

May the wise be respected,
And may alms be obtained.
May the mind be completely pure,
And may [our] renown spread in all directions.

May they not experience the sufferings of the lower realms,
And without enduring hardships,
With bodies surpassing even the gods,
May they swiftly attain Buddhahood.

May all sentient beings repeatedly
Make offerings to all the Buddhas,
And through the inconceivable bliss of the Buddhas,
May they always be endowed with happiness.

May the bodhisattvas accomplish
The benefit of beings, as they intend in their hearts.
Whatever the Protector has in mind,
May that be fulfilled for all sentient beings.

Likewise, may the Pratyekabuddhas
And the Śrāvakas also be happy.
Through the kindness of Manjushri,
May I attain the stage of utmost joy.
May I always remember my past lives,
And may I attain ordination.

May I, even through my food and drink,
Be endowed with spiritual experiences and sustain my life.
In all my lifetimes, may I dwell in solitude,
And attain perfect abundance.

When I wish to behold him,
Or even ask the slightest question,
May I see that very protector Manjushri
Without any obstacles.

For the sake of accomplishing the benefit of all sentient beings
Throughout the ten directions to the limits of space,
Just as Manjushri acts,
May my conduct also be the same.

As long as space endures,
And as long as living beings remain,
Until then, may I too abide,
To dispel the misery of the world.

Whatever sufferings sentient beings may have,
May all of those ripen upon me.
Through the virtuous community of bodhisattvas,
May all beings enjoy happiness.

The sole medicine for the suffering of beings,
The source from which all happiness arises,
May the Dharma, along with its discovery, veneration,
And practice, long endure.

By whose kindness virtuous thoughts arise,
I bow to Manjushri.
By whose kindness I flourish,
I also bow to the virtuous spiritual friend.

This concludes the tenth chapter called "Dedication" from the "Guide to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life."

The "Guide to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life" composed by the master Shantideva is hereby completed.
